Its removal from the market underscores the global push to eliminate pesticides with significant human health hazards.

Fenbuconazole is a systemic triazole fungicide used to control fungal diseases on crops like peanuts, stone fruits (peaches), and turf grass. It inhibits sterol biosynthesis in fungi, protecting plants from leaf spot, rust, and blossom blight. Introduced in the 1990s, fenbuconazole (e.g., Indar®) was notably used in peach orchards to manage brown rot. It has both preventative and curative activity and was valued for its residual effectiveness and relatively narrow spectrum (primarily effective against Ascomycete fungi).
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary ingestion of residues on treated produce (for example, consuming peaches or plums that have been sprayed with fenbuconazole during the growing season). Some residue can also occur in peanut-derived products if used on peanut crops.
Occupational exposure for farmers and orchard sprayers through dermal and inhalation routes when mixing concentrates or during high-exposure activities like airblast spraying of trees.
Fenbuconazole is not used in households, and it is relatively immobile in soil, so non-occupational, non-dietary exposure (e.g., via drinking water) is expected to be very low.

summary_sections.content: Fenbuconazole has been shown in toxicology studies to affect reproduction and development in test animals. It is classified by the EU as a reproductive toxicant Category 1B (presumed to cause reproductive harm). In rodent studies, fenbuconazole caused reduced fertility and developmental delays at high doses, as well as liver enzyme induction and liver weight increases. It is of moderate acute toxicity (oral LD50 in rats ~ 1000 mg/kg). There is no clear evidence of carcinogenicity in two-year studies, but due to endocrine-related effects, it is handled as a Highly Hazardous Pesticide by some criteria. Fenbuconazole is metabolized and excreted in a matter of days; detection in human blood would imply recent exposure above background levels. Given its hazard profile, regulators consider any avoidable exposure to be undesirable.

Fenbuconazole is not approved in the EU; its registration was allowed to lapse, and it was officially withdrawn due to concerns including its classification as toxic to reproduction. In the US, fenbuconazole has had limited use (primarily on stone fruits and pecans) and is under periodic review by EPA. Many countries have either banned or restricted fenbuconazole, and it appears on some NGO lists of pesticides to phase out. As a result, international trade has low tolerance for fenbuconazole residues, and MRLs are set low (often at analytical detection limits). Monitoring programs like the EU-coordinated residue monitoring rarely find fenbuconazole above the limit of quantification now. It is not measured in human biomonitoring surveys. The regulatory trend is clearly toward global discontinuation; fenbuconazole’s example is cited in policy discussions about removing Category 1B repro-toxic pesticides from use.

Fluquinconazole is a triazole fungicide primarily used in seed treatment formulations to protect cereal crops (like wheat, barley) from seed-borne and soil-borne fungal diseases (such as smuts and bunts). It is a quinazoline-triazole derivative with systemic activity, ensuring emerging seedlings are protected. Fluquinconazole’s use was more specialized compared to foliar triazoles, focusing on ensuring healthy crop establishment.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary exposure is minimal since fluquinconazole is applied as a seed treatment (by the time the crop is harvested, residues in grain are extremely low or undetectable).
Occupational exposure for seed treatment workers or farmers handling treated seed (via skin contact with treated seeds or inhalation of seed dust during planting).
There is negligible consumer exposure aside from any trivial residues in final commodities, given its use pattern (not sprayed on growing plants).

summary_sections.content: Fluquinconazole’s toxicological data are not widely published, but as a triazole it likely shares class traits: low acute toxicity, but potential chronic effects on the liver and possibly developmental toxicity at high doses. In regulatory evaluations, it has been flagged for having a toxicological profile requiring detailed risk assessment, and the EU classified it as toxic to reproduction (Category 2) and environmentally persistent. It is not reported to be carcinogenic. With its use restricted to seed treatments, general population exposure is extremely low. Fluquinconazole is metabolized in animals within days to weeks. The presence of fluquinconazole in human blood would not be expected under normal conditions; if detected, it might indicate direct handling of concentrated product. Like other conazoles, it can cause some enzyme changes in mammals, so exposure controls are recommended for workers.

Fluquinconazole was never approved in the EU (the EU evaluation highlighted concerns about persistence and potential toxicity). Its use globally has been limited; some seed treatment products were registered in certain countries but have faced scrutiny. Many jurisdictions opted not to establish food tolerances for fluquinconazole, effectively prohibiting its presence in the food supply. Environmental monitoring shows fluquinconazole can persist in soil for some time (hence regulatory caution). It is not part of any human biomonitoring program, given its narrow application. Regulatory bodies maintain that if fluquinconazole is used, it should be strictly confined to seed treatment with measures to minimize dust-off and worker exposure. Ongoing reviews under international conventions (like the Stockholm Convention’s POPs review or Rotterdam Convention) have not listed it, but it remains a candidate for more restrictive measures if use were to expand.

Flusilazole is an organosilicon triazole fungicide once used on a variety of crops (including maize, soybeans, and fruit trees) to control fungal diseases such as rusts, leaf spots, and mildews. It was often applied as a foliar spray and had systemic action, protecting new growth. Flusilazole was effective at low application rates and often used in rotation or mixtures for resistance management. It is notable for containing a silicon atom in its structure, which was intended to improve rainfastness on plant surfaces.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary consumption of residues on treated crops (e.g., corn or fruits that had flusilazole applied before harvest). Prior to its ban, flusilazole residues could appear in grains or processed oils, though generally within regulated limits.

Occupational exposure for farmers or orchardists through handling and spraying activities (dermal absorption and inhalation of mists during application, particularly since flusilazole was used in high-acreage crops).
Flusilazole is somewhat persistent and could contaminate soil and water near treated fields, but significant exposure via drinking water was considered unlikely in risk assessments.

summary_sections.content: Flusilazole has a problematic toxicological profile: animal studies demonstrated that it is teratogenic (causing birth defects at relatively low doses) and hepatotoxic. It produced developmental malformations in rat and rabbit studies, including cleft palate and skeletal abnormalities, leading to its identification as a potent developmental toxin. It also induced liver tumors in chronic mouse studies. These findings led the EU to categorize flusilazole as a Category 1B reproductive toxicant and a suspected endocrine disruptor. Acute toxicity of flusilazole is moderate (not highly acutely poisonous, but it does irritate skin/eyes). Given its serious chronic effects, any detection of flusilazole or its metabolites in humans would be alarming, though unlikely now due to its discontinued use. Biomarkers of effect (like elevated liver enzymes or developmental outcomes) were key in its risk assessment.

Flusilazole was banned in the EU in 2008 after being among the first pesticides targeted under new hazard-based cut-off criteria for endocrine disruptors and developmental toxins. Since then, its use has been phased out globally. The EU set all flusilazole MRLs to the limit of detection, preventing any residues on imported food. The United States never registered flusilazole for use on food crops (it was evaluated but not approved). Other countries, such as those in Latin America and Asia, honored the global withdrawal to maintain trade with the EU. Flusilazole is thus no longer found in food monitoring surveys; any detection would trigger regulatory action. It is not part of human biomonitoring efforts given the expectation of zero exposure. The flusilazole case is often cited in discussions of removing harmful pesticides and the importance of hazard cut-off regulations to protect consumer health.

Flutriafol is a systemic triazole fungicide used to manage rusts and leaf spot diseases on crops like corn, soybeans, wheat, and sugar beets. It is often applied as a foliar spray and can also be used as a seed treatment. Flutriafol moves upward in plants, providing protective action on new growth. It has been employed widely in South America and Australia on row crops for diseases such as soybean rust. Its trade names include Topguard® among others.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary intake of residues on or in food (for example, grain or soy products from plants treated with flutriafol). Monitoring has shown low levels in some commodities, but within international limits.
Occupational exposure through dermal contact and inhalation for farmers during spraying or mixing (particularly in aerial application scenarios for rust control).

Flutriafol has moderate persistence in soil and can leach; thus, there is potential for ground or surface water exposure near heavy use areas, though drinking water contamination incidents have been rare.

summary_sections.content: Flutriafol is considered of moderate acute toxicity (Category III). It has been associated with effects on the liver and thyroid in animal studies. Chronic exposure led to liver hypertrophy and benign thyroid tumors in rats, suggesting hormonal perturbation. Flutriafol is classified as possibly carcinogenic (based on thyroid tumors in rodents) and has shown some developmental toxicity at high doses (e.g., reduced fetal weights). It is not a known genotoxin. Metabolism studies indicate flutriafol is relatively persistent in soils and plants, but in mammals it is excreted over days. Biomonitoring in farm worker studies found that proper PPE use keeps flutriafol exposure low. If detected in human blood, it would likely correlate with recent agricultural use without protective measures. The risk assessments incorporate safety factors to ensure dietary exposure stays below levels causing these thyroid or liver changes.

Flutriafol is approved in many countries (including the US since 2010 for certain uses, and previously in the EU until its approval expired in 2020). The EU opted not to renew flutriafol’s approval, aligning with hazard concerns, and now treats it as a non-approved substance (with low default MRLs). The US EPA maintains tolerances for flutriafol on a variety of crops (corn, soy, fruit), and continues to monitor new data, particularly about its potential endocrine effects. Food monitoring programs in North America occasionally detect flutriafol in produce, but typically below tolerance levels. Some importing countries have raised concern when detecting it on shipments from regions still using it. Flutriafol is not included in CDC’s biomonitoring list, but farm operator exposure is tracked in certain agricultural health studies. Regulatory attention on flutriafol focuses on ensuring that when it is used, application guidelines minimize environmental runoff and human exposure, and that alternatives are considered during re-evaluation cycles.

Hexaconazole is a systemic triazole fungicide used mainly in Asian agriculture on rice, fruits, and ornamentals to control fungal diseases like sheath blight, powdery mildew, and anthracnose. It inhibits ergosterol biosynthesis in fungi. Hexaconazole was popular in the 1990s and 2000s in countries like China and India for rice blast control and on mangoes and chili peppers to manage powdery mildew. It has curative and protective properties and is applied as a foliar spray.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary ingestion of residues on treated commodities (e.g., trace hexaconazole residues on rice grains, mango skins, or other produce). Countries using hexaconazole have MRLs to control these residue levels in food.
Occupational exposure for workers mixing and applying hexaconazole (dermal contact during spraying and inhalation of spray mists, especially in paddy field conditions without mechanization).
Minimal other exposure pathways exist, as hexaconazole was not used in homes and tends to bind to soil (so groundwater contamination is limited).

summary_sections.content: Hexaconazole is moderately toxic if swallowed (acute oral LD50 ~ 1000 mg/kg in rats) and exhibits typical triazole toxic effects: liver enlargement, enzyme induction, and some developmental toxicity at high doses. In animal studies, hexaconazole caused maternal toxicity and fetal growth retardation; it is classified as suspected of damaging the unborn child (Repr. Category 2) in some jurisdictions. It is not identified as genotoxic. Long-term studies showed liver tumors in mice (classifying it as a possible carcinogen). With routine exposures (dietary or bystander) being very low, significant human health effects are not expected; however, chronic high exposures (e.g., in formulation workers) could theoretically pose risk to liver function or endocrine balance. The presence of hexaconazole in human fluids would signal recent exposure—likely dietary from imported foods or occupational—since it is metabolized and eliminated over a period of days in mammals.

Hexaconazole is not approved in the EU or US, but continues to be registered in various Asian and South American countries. The EU evaluated hexaconazole but did not list it for Annex I inclusion, citing insufficient data on long-term effects. Many nations have established MRLs for hexaconazole on certain crops to accommodate its use elsewhere, but the trend is toward reducing reliance on it. Food monitoring in Europe occasionally flagged hexaconazole on imported produce in the past, which contributed to stricter import requirements and alternative fungicide recommendations. It is not part of NHANES or other large biomonitoring surveys in the West. Regulatory bodies like CODEX have an extraneous maximum residue limit (EMRL) for hexaconazole on some commodities, ensuring international trade safety. As newer fungicides (with more favorable profiles) replace it, hexaconazole is expected to be gradually phased out globally, and regulatory monitoring will focus on confirming its decline in food and the environment.

Ipconazole is a triazole fungicide primarily used as a seed treatment. It protects seeds and seedlings of crops like corn, canola, and cereals from soil-borne and seed-borne fungal diseases (such as smuts, bunts, and seedling blights). It has a cyclopentyl structure that differentiates it slightly from other triazoles, conferring effective control at low use rates. Ipconazole is not used as a foliar spray; its domain is in treating seeds prior to planting to ensure healthy crop establishment.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary exposure is negligible because ipconazole is applied to seeds (by harvest time, residues in edible parts are either extremely low or undetectable). Regulatory risk assessments often consider ipconazole residues as not likely to transfer significantly to grain.

Occupational exposure for workers in seed treatment facilities or during planting of treated seed (via skin contact with treated seed or inhalation of dust from treated seed, which is why dust-reducing formulations are used).
No direct consumer product uses; ipconazole is confined to the agricultural seed industry, so exposure for the general public outside of diet is essentially zero.

summary_sections.content: Ipconazole is of moderate acute toxicity. It can be slightly irritating to skin and eyes. In toxicological studies, ipconazole showed effects typical of triazoles: at high doses in animals it caused liver weight increases and some signs of developmental toxicity (e.g., delayed skeletal ossification in fetuses at maternally toxic doses). It is not considered carcinogenic based on available data, and there is no evidence of genotoxicity. Ipconazole is metabolized and eliminated relatively quickly in animals. Given the low exposure scenarios (seed treatment residues in diet are minimal), human health risk is considered low. If biomonitoring were conducted on seed treatment workers, one might detect ipconazole or its metabolites shortly after intense exposure, but such monitoring is not routine. Standard PPE and engineering controls in seed treatment processes keep worker exposures to low, acceptable levels.

Ipconazole is approved in several countries (including the US, Canada, EU) strictly for seed treatment uses. Regulatory agencies have evaluated it and often set very low or exempt residue tolerances for commodities since exposure via food is minimal. For instance, the US EPA established tolerance exemptions for some crops when used as a seed treatment at specified application rates. The EU approved ipconazole, and its use is covered by harmonized seed treatment guidelines. It is not monitored in food surveillance programs because it does not appear in commodities at harvest. Environmental monitoring focuses on runoff from treated seeds (which is generally a minor concern due to low volumes used). Ipconazole is not included in human biomonitoring programs. The regulatory stance on ipconazole is that it is acceptable for controlled use in seed treatments; periodic reviews ensure that the seed treatment practices (such as dust suppression and label instructions) mitigate any exposure to workers and ecosystems.

Metconazole is a triazole fungicide used on field crops (like corn, soybeans, peanuts, and small grains) to control foliar fungal diseases such as rusts, leaf spots, and blights. It has both preventative and curative activity and is systemic, moving within plant tissues. Metconazole is also used in some turf grass management. It was introduced in the 2000s and is a component of certain combination fungicide products to broaden disease control spectrum.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary ingestion of residues on treated crops (e.g., very low levels of metconazole or its metabolites might be present in grain, peanuts, or peanut oil from treated fields; these are monitored against tolerance limits).
Occupational exposure by applicators during mixing and spraying (dermal absorption and inhalation can occur, especially in aerial or high-pressure ground spraying).

Metconazole is not used residentially. It is moderately persistent in soil but tends to stay in the topsoil, so contamination of groundwater or drinking water is considered unlikely for general population exposure.

summary_sections.content: Metconazole is of moderate acute toxicity (requiring WARNING labels on concentrate products). Toxicological studies show metconazole can cause developmental and reproductive effects in animals; in fact, the EU classified it as toxic for reproduction Category 2. Effects observed included fetal skeletal variations and reduced pup weights at maternally toxic doses. Additionally, metconazole exposure in rodents led to increased liver weights and some benign thyroid tumors (indicative of endocrine interaction at high doses). It is not considered a genotoxic compound. Due to these findings, exposure limits are kept low. Metconazole is metabolized in mammals and excreted mostly via urine. Human biomonitoring data are not publicly available, but if measured, one might use urinary metabolites as a marker of recent exposure for farm workers. In general, with proper protective equipment, health risk to applicators is mitigated, and dietary risk assessments by EPA/EFSA indicate it is below levels of concern for consumers under existing use patterns.

Metconazole is approved in the US and many countries for use on food crops, with established tolerances/MRLs (e.g., EPA tolerances on corn, soy, peanut, etc.). In the EU, metconazole has been approved in the past, but as of recent reviews it was not renewed, largely due to its classification as a reproductive toxin (leading to non-approval under hazard cut-off criteria). Consequently, the EU has set MRLs at default low levels and its use in Europe has ceased. In the US, it remains available (for example, in fungicide products for soybeans against Asian soybean rust). Monitoring programs like the USDA’s PDP include metconazole in their analyte lists, but findings in food are infrequent and generally low. It is not part of NHANES biomonitoring. Manufacturers have had to provide extensive data on metconazole’s long-term effects for registration, and regulators continue to review new data under periodic re-evaluation schemes. If international trade contains traces of metconazole, importing countries ensure compliance with their strict residue standards, reflecting a cautious approach to this fungicide because of its toxicological profile.

Myclobutanil is a systemic triazole fungicide widely used to control powdery mildew, rust, and other fungal diseases on crops such as grapes, apples, cherries, and ornamental plants. It was sold under trade names like Rally® and Eagle® for agricultural and turf applications. Myclobutanil was also infamously detected as an illegal additive on cannabis plants (due to its mildew control efficacy) in some jurisdictions, drawing attention to its residues when combusted. Its mode of action is inhibition of ergosterol biosynthesis in fungi.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary ingestion of residues on treated fruits and vegetables (e.g., apples or grapes sprayed with myclobutanil retain low residues on their skin). These residues are monitored and are generally below tolerance limits when used legally.

Occupational exposure for farm and greenhouse workers (via skin contact or inhalation during mixing, loading, or spraying, and during re-entry into recently treated fields without proper protective clothing).

Inhalation exposure from combustion: myclobutanil gained notoriety when found on cannabis; if burned, it can decompose to toxic gases (e.g., hydrogen cyanide), posing inhalation risks to users of tainted cannabis. This is a unique exposure pathway not relevant to food crops but noted in public health contexts.

summary_sections.content: Myclobutanil is of moderate acute toxicity (oral LD50 ~ 1600 mg/kg in rats) and is classified as slightly toxic by EPA (Category III). It can cause eye irritation but is not a strong skin sensitizer. Chronic studies in animals indicate myclobutanil can cause liver and testicular effects at high doses; some evidence of skeletal variations in offspring was observed in developmental studies, but it is not considered a primary teratogen. It is classified in the EU as toxic to reproduction Category 2 (suspected of damaging the unborn). Myclobutanil is not listed as a carcinogen, though some rodent studies showed increased benign thyroid tumors at very high doses. A distinctive aspect of myclobutanil is that when heated (above its decomposition point), it can release toxic fumes (the hydrogen cyanide issue noted above). Under normal agricultural exposure, this isn’t a factor, but it became a health concern in illicit cannabis contexts. Biological monitoring could measure  hydroxy-myclobutanil metabolites in urine for exposed workers; in general, typical dietary exposures have been deemed low risk by regulators. The detection of any significant level of myclobutanil in humans would usually point to unusual exposure scenarios, given current controls.

Myclobutanil is approved for agricultural use in the US, Canada, and many countries, though the EU withdrew its approval in 2019 amid concerns under updated hazard criteria. Residue tolerances exist (for example, US tolerances on apples, grapes, etc.), and food monitoring regularly tests for myclobutanil. It is among the more commonly detected fungicides on produce, but usually within safe limits. After high-profile cases of myclobutanil misuse on cannabis (where no tolerance exists), several US states banned its use on cannabis and improved testing requirements. Because of this, regulatory scrutiny of myclobutanil expanded beyond traditional food safety into product safety for cannabis in jurisdictions where it is legal. Environmental agencies monitor water runoff from orchards and vineyards for triazoles like myclobutanil, but it’s not considered a major water contaminant. In occupational safety, guidelines and re-entry intervals are established to protect workers. As of now, myclobutanil remains available for farmers in many parts of the world (outside the EU), and international trade tolerances accommodate its residues on exported produce. It’s not included in human biomonitoring programs like NHANES. However, its presence and consequences in the cannabis context have added a new layer to its regulatory narrative, prompting cross-sector discussions on pesticide use outside of food agriculture.

Paclobutrazol is a triazole compound primarily used as a plant growth regulator rather than a fungicide. It inhibits gibberellin biosynthesis, leading to reduced plant shoot growth and more compact form. In horticulture, paclobutrazol is applied to fruit trees (e.g., mango orchards to synchronize flowering), ornamental plants, and turfgrass to manage growth and improve stress tolerance. It does have some ancillary fungicidal activity (due to its triazole structure), but its main commercial role is growth regulation (e.g., marketed in products like Bonzi® for ornamental plant height control).
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary exposure is minimal. Paclobutrazol is used in ways that do not typically result in residues on food commodities, except possibly trace amounts in fruits from treated trees (e.g., mangos). Any such residues are monitored and generally low, as applications are often soil-based or early in the season.

Occupational exposure can occur for nursery and greenhouse workers applying paclobutrazol drenches or sprays to ornamentals (dermal contact or inhalation of mist) and for farmers applying it to orchards.

Environmental exposure could happen if paclobutrazol leaches into soil or water (it is somewhat persistent and can move in soil), but since it’s not heavily used on large-field crops, widespread environmental exposure is limited.

summary_sections.content: Paclobutrazol is of low to moderate acute toxicity (oral LD50 in rats ~1300 mg/kg). It is not well-studied as a toxin in humans, but animal studies indicate it can affect liver enzymes and cause slight developmental delays at high doses (likely via its hormone-modulating effects). It is not classified as a carcinogen or known endocrine disruptor in humans, but its mode of action in plants (gibberellin inhibition) suggests potential for hormonal effects in mammals at sufficient exposure. That said, typical human exposure levels are extremely low. If paclobutrazol were detected in human blood or urine, it would probably stem from an occupational setting. It is metabolized and excreted mainly via feces in animals. Overall, paclobutrazol’s risk profile is considered favorable enough for its regulatory approvals as a growth regulator, with safety precautions focusing on worker handling.

Paclobutrazol is registered in many countries for non-food uses (ornamentals, turf) and selected food uses (e.g., certain fruit orchards). The US EPA and other agencies have established tolerances for paclobutrazol residues in some fruits (like stone fruits) where it might be used. The EU reviewed paclobutrazol and did not approve it as a pesticide active (partly since its main function is as a plant growth regulator and there were limited food uses). Countries like India and Australia allow paclobutrazol on mango and other fruit trees under good agricultural practice limits. Food monitoring rarely tests for paclobutrazol because of its limited direct use on consumable portions; it has occasionally been looked for in fruit like mango (with no concerning findings). It’s not included in human biomonitoring programs due to expected negligible exposure. Worker safety regulations treat paclobutrazol similarly to low-toxicity pesticides: requiring standard PPE during mixing and application. The regulatory stance is that paclobutrazol, when used according to label for growth management, poses minimal risk to human health or the environment, and thus it remains available in specialty agricultural markets.

Penconazole is a systemic triazole fungicide used to control powdery mildew and other fungal diseases on vines (grapevines), cucurbit vegetables, and ornamentals. It inhibits ergosterol biosynthesis in fungi. Historically, penconazole (brand name Topaze® and others) was applied in vineyards to protect grapes from powdery mildew, and in greenhouse ornamentals. It has curative and preventive action and was one of the earlier triazoles introduced for specialty crops in the 1980s.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary exposure from residues on treated produce, especially wine grapes and some vegetables. Wine made from treated grapes can contain trace penconazole residues, which have been monitored by regulatory agencies.
Occupational exposure for farmers, vineyard workers, and greenhouse applicators through dermal contact and inhalation during spraying and pruning of treated plants.
No significant residential exposure; penconazole wasn’t used in consumer garden products in most regions.

summary_sections.content: Penconazole has moderate acute toxicity (oral LD50 ~ 500 mg/kg in rats). Animal studies indicate that penconazole affects the liver and can cause developmental toxicity (fetal skeletal variations, etc., at high maternal doses). It is classified in the EU as a Category 2 reproductive toxicant (suspected of harming the unborn). Long-term studies in rodents did not show strong carcinogenic effects, though like many triazoles, some liver hypertrophy and benign tumors were observed at high doses. It is not considered genotoxic. In humans, potential health concerns center on chronic exposure leading to liver enzyme changes or endocrine effects, which is why safety margins are applied. If penconazole or its metabolites were measured in humans, it would likely correlate with significant recent dietary or occupational exposure. Given its phase-out in many areas, current general population levels are expected to be negligible. Penconazole is metabolized and primarily excreted via urine.

Penconazole is no longer approved in the EU (its authorization was not renewed due to its hazard classification), and its use has been discontinued in many countries. Some countries allowed it on certain crops (e.g., it was once used in New Zealand on cucurbits), but global usage is now limited. The EU and other importers have set low MRLs (at or near detection limits) for penconazole on foods, effectively banning its presence. During its period of use, monitoring programs did occasionally detect penconazole residues on grapes and in wines, which were reported but generally below then-established limits. Currently, penconazole is not part of routine pesticide residue screens in major markets because it’s not expected. It’s not included in human biomonitoring surveys either. Regulatory bodies that banned penconazole did so under the precautionary principle, substituting it with fungicides that pose fewer potential risks. Any detection of penconazole in commerce now tends to trigger regulatory alerts, as it may indicate either old stock use or illegal application. Thus, the compound serves as an example of a once-useful fungicide phased out in the pursuit of safer alternatives.

Propiconazole is a broad-spectrum triazole fungicide widely used in agriculture (and turf management) to control fungal diseases on cereals, peanuts, coffee, stone fruits, and lawns. It was commonly sold under trade names like Tilt® and Banner®. Propiconazole is systemic and protects against rusts, leaf spots, and mildews by inhibiting fungal sterol synthesis. It has been one of the workhorse fungicides in grain production since the 1990s, valued for its reliability and relatively low phytotoxicity.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary ingestion of residues on treated commodities (e.g., wheat, barley, or fruits that received propiconazole sprays). Residues can also occur in processed products like flour or juice, but generally within regulated limits.
Occupational exposure for farmers, applicators, and golf course/turf workers (dermal and inhalation routes during mixing, spraying, or when entering treated fields/greens before sprays have dried).

Propiconazole has been used as a wood preservative component in some formulations, so carpenters or wood treatment workers could have exposure if handling treated timber, albeit on a smaller scale than agricultural use.

summary_sections.content: Propiconazole has moderate acute toxicity. It is classified as likely to be carcinogenic to humans by the US EPA (based on thyroid tumors observed in male rats). It also showed developmental toxicity in animal studies (e.g., reduced fetal weights) and has been implicated in possible endocrine-disrupting effects (propiconazole affects steroid metabolism). EU regulators consider it an endocrine disruptor and a presumed human reproductive toxicant. Subchronic exposures caused liver enlargement and adrenal effects in rodents. Despite these concerns, typical dietary exposures were estimated to be below levels causing these effects. Propiconazole is metabolized and excreted in days; any substantial level found in human blood/urine would indicate a recent, relatively high exposure (most likely occupational, given declining dietary exposure after regulatory bans). Medical surveillance of heavily exposed workers (pre-ban) noted potential effects on liver enzymes, underscoring the need for protective measures.

Propiconazole’s regulatory status has diverged: it was not approved for renewal in the EU (ceased use by 2019) specifically because it was identified as an endocrine disrupting chemical and did not meet the cut-off criteria for safety. Consequently, the EU banned its use and now enforces a near-zero tolerance for its residues on imports. In the US and other countries, propiconazole was still in use through the late 2010s with EPA tolerances in place, but manufacturers voluntarily canceled many propiconazole product registrations, and its agricultural use is winding down due to market and regulatory pressure. Pesticide residue monitoring in the past did detect propiconazole on foods like peanuts and grains, but those detections are becoming rare with reduced use. It is not in human biomonitoring programs, but environmental agencies keep track of its occurrence in surface waters and sediments (given its moderate persistence). The case of propiconazole illustrates the strengthening of health-protective regulations—what was once a widely allowed fungicide is being removed globally to prevent even potential health risks associated with endocrine disruption and other chronic effects.

Prothioconazole is a modern triazole fungicide (actually a thiazole-carboxamide precursor that rapidly converts to a triazole form in plants) used extensively on cereal crops (wheat, barley), oilseed rape (canola), and peanuts. It has a broad spectrum, controlling Fusarium head blight, leaf spots, rusts, and other diseases. Prothioconazole was introduced in the mid-2000s (e.g., trade name Proline®) and became widely adopted due to its efficacy and perceived improved safety profile compared to older triazoles. It is often used in mixtures to manage resistance and broaden disease control.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary ingestion of residues on treated grains and oilseeds (e.g., low levels of prothioconazole and its metabolites can be present in wheat grain or peanut kernels, but mostly below tolerance limits set by regulators). Processing (like milling or oil extraction) often reduces residues further.

Occupational exposure for farmers and custom applicators during spraying (dermal and inhalation) and for workers handling recently sprayed crops (e.g., during harvest, though observance of re-entry intervals mitigates this).
No residential or urban use; prothioconazole is confined to commercial agriculture, so general public exposure outside food is negligible.

summary_sections.content: Prothioconazole has low acute toxicity (Category III). It is rapidly converted in plants and animals to prothioconazole-desthio, which is the biologically active triazole alcohol metabolite. Toxicologically, prothioconazole-desthio is similar to other triazoles: high doses in lab animals led to liver enlargement, enzyme induction, and developmental effects (e.g., post-implantation losses in rabbits, indicative of embryo-fetal toxicity at maternally toxic doses). Prothioconazole is classified by the EU as a presumed human reproductive toxicant (Category 1B) due to these effects. It is not genotoxic; and long-term studies did not show significant carcinogenicity, though some increase in liver tumors in mice was noted (interpreted via a non-genotoxic mechanism). Human risk assessments consider the combined exposure to prothioconazole and its desthio metabolite. These compounds are metabolized and excreted within days; detecting them in human urine would reflect recent intake (studies in farmers show low urinary levels after spraying when PPE is used). The primary health concern is chronic dietary or occupational exposure potentially affecting reproductive parameters or liver function, hence the strict regulatory limits.

Prothioconazole has been approved and widely used in the EU, US, and other grain-producing regions, often touted as a safer alternative to older triazoles. However, during recent EU hazard-based reviews, prothioconazole was identified as meeting the cut-off for reproductive toxicity Category 1B. Its approval in the EU was renewed up until 2022 with certain restrictions, but future renewals became uncertain under the hazard criteria. The EU currently classifies it as a Candidate for Substitution, meaning regulators seek alternatives. Meanwhile, the US and other jurisdictions maintain tolerances (the EPA tolerance for wheat grain, e.g., is 0.01 ppm) and enforce pre-harvest intervals to ensure residues dissipate. Monitoring programs (like EFSA’s yearly residue report) have occasionally detected prothioconazole-desthio on cereals but typically at low levels. It is not part of human biomonitoring surveys (no NHANES measurements) because exposure is mainly among those consuming unprocessed grains at high frequency (or occupationally). Regulators continue to watch for any health signals; the extensive use of prothioconazole in the last decade means its phase-out could have significant agricultural impact, so regulatory bodies are carefully balancing agricultural needs with health protection in decisions on its future status.

Tebuconazole is a widely used triazole fungicide applied to a broad array of crops including cereals (wheat, corn), nuts (peanuts), grapes, bananas, and ornamental plants. It protects against diseases like rusts, powdery mildew, leaf spots, and Fusarium (head blight). First introduced in the early 1990s (one well-known formulation is Folicur®), tebuconazole became popular due to its strong efficacy and relatively long protective window. It’s also used in seed treatment and sometimes turfgrass management. Tebuconazole’s broad usage made it one of the most prevalent triazole fungicides in global agriculture.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary ingestion of residues on treated food commodities: for example, trace tebuconazole can be found in grain products, wine (from treated grapes), and fruits (apples, bananas). These residues are monitored by agencies to ensure they remain below MRLs.

Occupational exposure for applicators and farm workers via dermal contact and inhalation during mixing/loading and spraying, and via contact with treated crops (e.g., harvesting peanuts or pruning grapevines shortly after application).

Incidental exposure through the environment is possible; tebuconazole has been detected in agricultural runoff and occasionally in surface waters near heavy-use areas, though typically at low concentrations. It is not used in residential settings, so general public exposure is mainly through diet.

summary_sections.content: Tebuconazole is of moderate acute toxicity (ingestion can cause gastrointestinal and neurological symptoms at high doses in lab animals). Chronic studies revealed that tebuconazole causes liver enlargement and induced liver tumors in mice, and it has been classified by US EPA as a possible human carcinogen (based on those mouse liver tumors). It also produces developmental toxicity in animals; for instance, it caused birth defects (like skeletal anomalies and hydrocephaly) in rat fetuses at high doses, leading to its classification in the EU as toxic to reproduction Category 2. Tebuconazole may affect the hormonal balance (studies have noted impacts on the enzyme aromatase and steroid levels). It does not appear to be genotoxic. In humans, acute poisoning cases are rare; risk is primarily from chronic exposure, which is controlled by regulation. Tebuconazole is metabolized with a half-life on the order of days in animals, with excretion via urine/feces. It could be measured via specific metabolites in urine for biomonitoring, but this isn’t routinely done. The presence of low levels of tebuconazole in blood would indicate recent exposure, likely dietary or occupational, given its continuous use up until recently.

Tebuconazole has been one of the most widely allowed fungicides, but regulatory attitudes are shifting. The EU renewed tebuconazole approval in the 2000s but has since designated it a candidate for substitution due to its toxicological profile; its approval was not renewed in 2021, effectively banning its use in EU agriculture. Prior to that ban, the EU and other regulators had already cut back permissible residues (for example, baby food in the EU had a zero tolerance for tebuconazole). The US EPA still permits tebuconazole on many crops, with set tolerances (e.g., 0.05 ppm on wheat grain, 0.01 ppm on bananas). Food monitoring data frequently listed tebuconazole among detected residues on imported produce (like South American bananas or European wine); with the EU ban, one can expect those residues to decline over time. Tebuconazole is not included in CDC’s biomonitoring program, although specialized studies (like the Canadian Total Diet Study) have tracked its dietary intake. Going forward, many countries are phasing out or limiting tebuconazole in favor of less hazardous fungicides, aligning with the global trend to reduce consumer exposure to endocrine-active and carcinogenic agents. Meanwhile, import tolerances and periodic monitoring ensure that any interim residues in traded goods remain within safety margins.

Tetraconazole is a systemic triazole fungicide used mainly on vines (grapevines) and sugar beets to control powdery mildew and Cercospora leaf spot, respectively. It’s also applied on some fruiting vegetables and turf. Tetraconazole inhibits sterol biosynthesis in fungi, stopping disease spread. Introduced in the 1990s, it provided another tool for viticulture disease management. It is often applied in multiple low-rate sprays through the season (e.g., in vineyards) for continuous protection against mildew.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary exposure from treated produce, primarily wine grapes and sugar derived from treated sugar beets. Residues in wine made from tetraconazole-treated grapes have been monitored, usually finding very low levels (most tetraconazole remains in grape pomace rather than juice).

Occupational exposure for farmers and vineyard sprayers (dermal contact and inhalation). Vineyard workers re-entering fields too soon after spraying might also get low-level dermal exposure if protective clothing is not worn.

Tetraconazole has limited home or urban use, so general public exposure outside of diet and environment is minimal. It is moderately persistent in soil, hence trace amounts could be found in farm adjacent soils or water runoff.

summary_sections.content: Tetraconazole exhibits moderate toxicity. It’s not acutely highly toxic (LD50 in rats ~ 1500 mg/kg) but has shown chronic effects in lab animals. Rats exposed over time developed liver changes and females showed uterine and ovarian effects, suggesting hormonal disturbances. Tetraconazole is classified in the EU as toxic to reproduction Category 2 (suspected of harming fertility or unborn). Some studies indicated developmental delays in offspring at maternally toxic doses. It is not considered genotoxic; carcinogenicity studies did not conclusively show cancer increases, although any endocrine disruption raises some concern for tumor promotion indirectly. In humans, risk assessments ensure dietary intake is below the level that caused hormonal effects in animals by large safety margins. If biomonitoring were to look for tetraconazole, likely urinary metabolites would be the marker, but such data are scarce. The precautionary principle suggests limiting exposure; detection in human tissue would be unusual and point to significant recent spray work or unusual dietary patterns (like excessive unwashed grape consumption from treated vineyards).

Tetraconazole has been approved in various jurisdictions (EU, US, South America) but is under increased scrutiny. The EU renewed tetraconazole up to 2019 but eventually did not renew it further, effectively banning its use (due in part to its classification as a potential reproductive toxin). Tetraconazole-containing products have been phased out in the EU, and MRLs were lowered to default levels for most commodities. In the US, tetraconazole is approved on sugar beets and pecans among others, with tolerances (e.g., 0.15 ppm on sugar beet roots). Routine monitoring (like EFSA’s report) occasionally found tetraconazole on imported produce, but with the EU ban, those detections will likely cease. Notably, the EU in 2018 identified tetraconazole as meeting endocrine disruptor criteria, marking it for priority removal. It’s not measured in human biomonitoring surveys. Countries that still allow it often label it as a candidate for substitution and restrict application timing (e.g., not near harvest) to minimize residues. The global trend is leaning towards non-renewal as current approvals lapse, in alignment with stricter hazard-based regulation. Meanwhile, regulatory enforcement ensures no significant residues of tetraconazole are present on foods in markets where it’s no longer authorized.

Triadimefon is a systemic triazole fungicide that was extensively used on cereal grains, turfgrass, and fruit crops (e.g., pineapples) to control powdery mildew, rusts, and other fungal pathogens. Marketed originally under the trade name Bayleton®, triadimefon was introduced in the 1970s and became a common fungicide on golf course turf and in wheat/barley farming. It acts by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis in fungi, providing protective and some curative action. Triadimefon also converts to triadimenol (another fungicide) in plants and animals, which contributes to its fungicidal effect.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary intake of residues on treated crops (for example, minute amounts of triadimefon/triadimenol might be present in grain products or on pineapples that were treated pre-harvest). Historically, some barley malt (for beer) had Bayleton residues when it was used in barley fields, all within regulated limits of the time.

Occupational exposure for applicators and turf managers (dermal contact and inhalation during mixing and spraying, especially on windy days on golf courses or large fields). Also, golfers or turf maintenance staff could be secondarily exposed if playing or working on freshly treated greens (leading to some countries issuing re-entry guidelines).
Triadimefon use in residential lawn products was limited but existed, so homeowners applying older stock fungicides to lawns could have minor exposure via skin contact or drift inhalation.

summary_sections.content: Triadimefon has been well studied toxicologically. It is moderately acutely toxic (Category III). Key concerns are chronic and developmental effects: in animal studies, triadimefon caused hyperactivity and developmental neurotoxicity in rodent offspring at high doses, as well as liver hypertrophy and benign thyroid tumors in chronic studies. It is classified by US EPA as a Group E (evidence of non-carcinogenicity for humans) based on available data, but more recent perspectives flag its neurobehavioral effects. Triadimefon can disrupt dopamine levels in the brain of rodents, which explained the hyperactivity observed. It is not strongly genotoxic. Triadimefon is metabolized partially to triadimenol; both compounds can be found in urine after exposure. Human poisoning cases are rare, but symptoms might include dizziness, nausea, or CNS stimulation. The detection of triadimefon or its metabolite in a human would indicate fairly recent exposure, as they are cleared in a matter of days. Because of these findings, regulators imposed lower safe exposure thresholds and ultimately phased it out in many uses to prevent any potential risk, particularly to children (e.g., playing on treated turf).

Triadimefon use has been phased out or banned in many regions. The EU did not include triadimefon in Annex I (it was not supported for re-registration), effectively banning it in the early 2000s. The US cancelled turf and residential uses by 2006 and later food crop uses as well; by the mid-2010s, triadimefon was largely obsolete in US agriculture. Many other countries followed suit, given availability of safer alternatives. In the era of its usage, residue monitoring did find triadimefon/triadimenol on foods like pineapples and grains, but generally within allowable levels. Now, such residues are rarely if ever detected in international trade. Triadimefon is not measured in contemporary biomonitoring surveys due to its discontinued status. Regulatory focus has moved to ensuring no old stock is illegally used. Triadimefon’s legacy influenced the development of stricter guidelines for assessing developmental neurotoxicity in pesticide registration. It stands as an example of a pesticide removed from widespread use as precautionary measures intensified, particularly to protect children’s health on treated surfaces and the food supply from subtle neurological risks.

Triadimenol is a systemic triazole fungicide and the major metabolite of triadimefon. It has been used as a seed treatment and foliar fungicide on cereals and other crops to control smuts, bunts, rusts, and mildews. Because triadimenol often exists as an impurity or metabolic conversion from triadimefon, some commercial products contained triadimenol directly (especially as seed treatments for barley and wheat). It inhibits ergosterol synthesis in fungi, protecting seedlings and plants from infection. Its usage overlapped with triadimefon’s era, and it gradually declined as newer fungicides replaced the older triazoles.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary exposure via consumption of products from treated grain (for example, flour from triadimenol-treated wheat or beer from treated barley could contain tiny residual amounts of triadimenol or its metabolites). Historically, these were monitored to ensure they remained below tolerance levels.

Occupational exposure during handling of triadimenol-treated seed (dust inhalation or skin contact at seed processing plants or during planting) and during any foliar spray applications (similar dermal/inhalation routes to other fungicides).

Triadimenol was not used in domestic settings; hence, general public exposure is mainly dietary or environmental (e.g., potential runoff into water from treated fields, though its use was less pervasive in later years).

summary_sections.content: Triadimenol’s toxicological profile is similar to triadimefon’s, given their close relationship. It is moderately acutely toxic (oral LD50 ~ 1000 mg/kg in rats). In animal studies, triadimenol affected liver enzyme activity and caused some degree of developmental toxicity (e.g., minor skeletal variations) at high doses, but generally required higher doses than triadimefon to produce effects. It has not shown significant carcinogenic effects in long-term studies, though it was less studied than its parent compound. There is evidence triadimenol can act as a weak estrogenic agent in some assays (due to being a chiral molecule with potentially different isomer activities). Human risk assessments treat triadimenol and triadimefon together, as exposures often co-occurred. Triadimenol is metabolized and excreted in urine and feces within a few days. It is not known to be neurotoxic in the way triadimefon is (with hyperactivity), but due to limited distinct data, it’s presumed to share some neurobehavioral caution. If found in human tissue, it would indicate direct exposure; however, nowadays it’s unlikely except perhaps in legacy cases or specific occupational scenarios.

Triadimenol, like triadimefon, was phased out in the EU and many other places. It was not separately approved in the EU after new regulations took effect, and any plant protection products containing it were withdrawn. The US did not have many uses for triadimenol outside of its presence via triadimefon conversion or certain seed treatment formulations, which are now obsolete. Residue monitoring for triadimenol on food is no longer routine since its usage has ended; earlier, it might have been detected on imported grains or hops but within allowed limits. Triadimenol is absent from national biomonitoring programs. Regulatory enforcement ensured that stocks were used up or disposed of by cutoff dates. The dual nature of triadimenol (somewhat included under triadimefon’s regulatory umbrella) means it effectively disappeared from markets when triadimefon did. Lessons from these compounds have influenced current pesticide registration, emphasizing thorough metabolic studies and considering the toxicity of both parent and metabolites in aggregate during risk assessments.

Triticonazole is a triazole fungicide used primarily as a seed treatment. It protects cereal seeds and seedlings (notably barley and wheat) from diseases like smuts and bunts, and it’s also used on sugar beet seeds to prevent damping-off. It is highly systemic in germinating seedlings, providing early-season disease control. Triticonazole was less commonly used as a foliar spray; its niche has been in ensuring healthy crop establishment via treated seed.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary exposure is very low. Since triticonazole is used on seeds, by harvest most of it has degraded or is present only in negligible amounts in the mature edible portions. As a result, residues in food commodities (flour, etc.) are usually undetectable or extremely low.

Occupational exposure for workers involved in seed treatment process (mixing triticonazole formulations with seed, bagging treated seed) through inhalation of seed dust and dermal contact. Also, farmers planting treated seed may contact chemical dust if not using closed cab planters or PPE.
Non-occupational exposure is minimal; triticonazole isn’t used in residential settings. Potentially, one could contact it by handling treated seeds, but that’s usually limited to farming contexts.

summary_sections.content: Triticonazole has relatively low acute toxicity (oral LD50 > 5000 mg/kg in rats in some studies, though formulation additives can influence this). There is limited public data on its chronic toxicity, but as a triazole, it likely shares some class effects such as mild liver enzyme induction at high doses. Regulatory reviews indicate that it is not classified as a carcinogen or known endocrine disruptor. It is considered a slight skin irritant. For workers handling triticonazole, short-term effects (if any) would likely be irritation from dust. Long-term animal feeding studies (if conducted) have not raised major red flags in available literature. Triticonazole is metabolized and excreted via typical pathways (urine/feces) over days to weeks. Human biomonitoring is not performed for triticonazole; any detection would most likely be in seed-treatment facility workers via urine metabolite analysis in a targeted occupational study. Overall, toxicologically it’s considered one of the more benign triazoles, aligning with its specialized seed treatment role (which inherently limits consumer exposure).

Triticonazole has been approved in the EU for seed treatment uses and was considered less of a priority for removal compared to foliar triazoles. It is still authorized in some jurisdictions for treating barley, wheat, and sugar beet seeds. MRLs for triticonazole in food are often set at the default low level (like 0.01 ppm) because significant residues in food are not expected. Monitoring programs seldom test for triticonazole explicitly due to its seed use pattern; instead, risk management is enforced at the seed treatment stage (licensing of facilities, safety protocols). Where it is approved, regulators require labeling with safety measures for workers (e.g., dust control, gloves, masks). The environmental regulators also examine seed treatment pesticides for their impact on soil and aquatic systems (triticonazole is moderately persistent but used in small quantities). Triticonazole is not listed in any major human biomonitoring or exposure reports, reflecting its low relevance to general population exposure. As regulatory landscapes become more hazard-oriented, triticonazole could face re-evaluation in the future, but for now it remains in a specialized, controlled use category with minimal human exposure by design.

Boscalid is a carboxamide (anilide) fungicide used to control a wide range of fungal diseases on crops like grapes, vegetables (e.g., lettuce), berries, and ornamentals. It is often used in combination with other fungicides (famously paired with pyraclostrobin in the product Pristine®) to broaden disease control and manage resistance. Boscalid works by inhibiting fungal respiration (succinate dehydrogenase inhibitor, SDHI), effectively stopping spore germination and mycelial growth. Introduced in the early 2000s, boscalid became widely adopted due to its broad efficacy against molds, mildews, and Botrytis on high-value crops.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary ingestion of residues on treated produce. Boscalid is commonly detected on fruits (like strawberries, grapes) and leafy greens as it is persistent on crop surfaces. Regulatory monitoring frequently finds boscalid residues, though typically within tolerance limits.

Occupational exposure for farmers and farmworkers during mixing, loading, and spraying boscalid-containing products (dermal and inhalation exposure to spray mist). Post-application, field re-entry can also lead to dermal contact with residues on foliage.

Boscalid has low volatility, so exposure via inhalation away from treated fields is limited. However, it is moderately persistent and can be found in soil and nearby water bodies from runoff, meaning there’s a potential route for environmental exposure (e.g., in well water near intense agriculture, albeit at low concentrations).

summary_sections.content: Boscalid has low acute toxicity (Category III by EPA). In animal studies, the primary effect of chronic exposure was an increase in thyroid and liver tumors in rats and mice at high doses. These tumorigenic effects are believed to be due to disruption of thyroid hormone balance at high exposure levels (from liver enzyme induction altering T4/T3 clearance). As a result, EPA classified boscalid as "Group E: evidence of non-carcinogenicity for humans" given that the mechanism (thyroid perturbation) is considered thresholded. No significant reproductive or developmental toxicity was noted at relevant doses; developmental studies showed effects only at maternally toxic doses. Boscalid is not genotoxic. It can cause mild liver weight increases in subchronic studies. It is fat-soluble and has been shown to bioaccumulate to some extent in fish, but in humans it’s metabolized and excreted over a period of days to weeks. If boscalid is detected in human blood or urine, it likely reflects recent dietary intake since it’s commonly present at low levels in fruits and vegetables. However, typical consumer exposures are far below doses that cause thyroid changes in animals, so such low-level presence isn’t considered a health risk by regulators under current guidelines.

Boscalid is approved in the US, EU, and many countries, and has become one of the more frequently detected fungicide residues on foods due to its widespread use on fruits and vegetables. Regulatory agencies (like EPA and EFSA) have established tolerances/MRLs for boscalid on dozens of crops (e.g., 3.5 ppm on strawberries in the US, 5 ppm on grapes in the EU, etc.). Monitoring data (e.g., USDA PDP and EFSA reports) routinely find boscalid on a variety of produce items, generally with the highest frequencies among all fungicides, but usually at concentrations well below the MRLs, indicating compliance with use directions. Boscalid has undergone periodic review; so far, its regulatory standing remains intact as its risk profile (thyroid tumors at high dose) is managed via large safety factors. It’s not included in standard human biomonitoring like NHANES, but special studies have measured boscalid in urine as part of pesticide panels and found it in a portion of the population, reflecting dietary exposure. With new European endocrine policies, boscalid’s thyroid effects are being scrutinized, but as of now it is not identified as an endocrine disruptor under EU criteria. Continual monitoring and re-evaluation are in place to ensure that boscalid’s presence in the diet stays at safe levels, and it remains an important tool for growers pending any new safety findings.

Carboxin is an oxathiin (carboxanilide) fungicide primarily used as a seed treatment to control smuts and bunts in cereal grains and other crops. Introduced in the 1960s (often under trade name Vitavax®), it became a standard treatment for wheat, barley, oats, and rye seeds to prevent seed-borne fungi from infecting seedlings. Carboxin specifically inhibits fungal mitochondrial respiration (complex II), effectively suppressing diseases like loose smut. It’s occasionally used in turfgrass as well. Its use has declined with newer seed treatments available, but it is still in limited use in some regions.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary exposure is minimal since carboxin is used on seeds. By harvest, residues in the edible grain are typically extremely low or non-detectable. Historically, residue studies showed near-complete degradation/dilution during plant growth.

Occupational exposure for seed treatment workers (dust inhalation and dermal contact when mixing carboxin with seed or handling treated seed). Also, farmers may be exposed to treated seed dust during planting if equipment isn’t enclosed.

Carboxin has essentially no residential use. It is moderately persistent in soil but applied in small quantities (on seeds), so environmental exposure (water, soil) beyond the immediate planting site is limited.

summary_sections.content: Carboxin is of low to moderate acute toxicity. It can cause mild skin and eye irritation. In chronic animal feeding studies, carboxin has not shown significant carcinogenicity; for example, long-term studies in rats and mice were mostly unremarkable aside from slight liver enlargement at high doses. It is not considered genotoxic. Carboxin’s main metabolite (BTCA) is also of low toxicity. Some older studies indicated that extremely high doses could affect liver and kidney weights in animals, but these levels far exceed any human exposure scenario. Reproductive and developmental studies did not indicate teratogenic or fertility issues at tested dose levels. In humans, accidental overexposure (which would likely only occur in an industrial setting) might cause symptoms like headache or nausea, but such cases are rare. Given the controlled manner of carboxin use, it’s not typically found in human bio-samples. Carboxin is metabolized and excreted relatively quickly; any absorption from handling treated seed would be cleared in urine within days. Overall, it’s considered a fungicide with a favorable safety profile, which is partly why it was widely adopted for seed treatments.

Carboxin has been registered and used for decades. It is still approved in the US and many countries as a seed treatment fungicide. Regulatory agencies have set tolerances for carboxin residues on raw agricultural commodities (in the US, e.g., 0.1 ppm on cereal grains), but actual residues are usually much lower or undetectable. The EU had carboxin on its positive list but some products were phased out as newer chemistries took over; it’s not broadly banned, but usage in Europe is now limited. Food monitoring programs seldom test for carboxin since exposure via diet is negligible. The focus is more on ensuring worker safety in seed treatment facilities: guidelines require dust reduction measures and personal protective equipment when handling carboxin powders. Because carboxin is an older compound, it underwent re-evaluation to ensure it meets modern safety standards. It has generally passed those re-evaluations or been gradually replaced by alternatives due to efficacy rather than acute safety issues. There’s no inclusion of carboxin in human biomonitoring efforts like NHANES, reflecting its minimal impact on consumers. In summary, carboxin remains a classic fungicide for targeted use, with regulatory oversight concentrating on industrial hygiene during its application to seeds.

Cyazofamid is a specialty fungicide used to control Oomycete pathogens (water molds) such as late blight (Phytophthora) and downy mildews on crops like potatoes, tomatoes, grapes, and cucurbits. It’s a cyano-imidazole compound that inhibits fungal respiration at complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex). Introduced in the early 2000s, cyazofamid is valued for its effectiveness against tough diseases like potato blight and its relatively low use rate. It has protectant activity and is often applied preventatively during conditions conducive to oomycete outbreaks.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary ingestion of residues on treated vegetables and fruits (e.g., potatoes or tomatoes sprayed with cyazofamid can carry tiny residues mainly on peels). Cyazofamid is used near harvest for late blight control, but MRLs are established to ensure safe levels in food.

Occupational exposure for field workers and applicators (via dermal contact and inhalation during spraying and when entering fields post-application). However, cyazofamid is often applied with ground equipment and good agricultural practice, limiting worker contact.

Cyazofamid is not used residentially. Environmental exposure could occur if it runs off into water bodies near treated fields, but it is moderately hydrophobic and tends to bind to soil; also, its specific target (oomycetes) has limited overlap with human biology, reducing direct toxicity concerns for aquatic life at typical run-off concentrations.

summary_sections.content: Cyazofamid has low acute toxicity (high LD50 in rats, Category III/IV toxicity class). It is not a skin sensitizer or irritant. Chronic toxicology studies in animals showed no carcinogenic effects and no significant reproductive or developmental toxicity. It is not genotoxic. The main effect observed at high doses was some liver hypertrophy in rats, but with no associated pathology. Regulatory agencies have not flagged cyazofamid for endocrine disruption potential. It is metabolized by cleavage of its phenyl and imidazole rings and excreted mostly in feces. Given its low toxicity profile, human health risk is considered low; typical dietary exposure is many times below the ADI. If monitored, cyazofamid or its metabolites might be detectable in urine of highly exposed individuals (like mixers), but no routine biomonitoring exists. The general public is unlikely to have measurable cyazofamid in their system from normal dietary patterns. In summary, cyazofamid is regarded as a fungicide with a favorable human safety profile, targeting fungal processes absent in humans.

Cyazofamid is approved in the US, EU, and other major agricultural markets, often with specific limitations (e.g., number of sprays per season to manage resistance). Regulatory evaluations by EPA and EFSA concluded that cyazofamid poses no carcinogenic or reproductive hazard, and established ADIs that are relatively high given its low toxicity. MRLs exist for relevant crops (e.g., in the EU: 0.1 mg/kg on potatoes, 2 mg/kg on grapes). Monitoring data seldom report cyazofamid residues on food, likely because its usage is targeted and it degrades on plants (plus washing and cooking of produce further reduce residues). Environmental monitoring indicates cyazofamid can be persistent in anaerobic conditions (like sediments), but breaks down in aerobic soil, which regulators accounted for in environmental risk assessments. No countries have moved to ban or severely restrict cyazofamid purely on health grounds; it’s largely seen as “reduced-risk.” It’s not included in human biomonitoring programs such as NHANES or the German ESB, reflecting both its low expected exposure and risk. As with many modern fungicides, ongoing regulatory oversight will periodically re-check its safety against new data, but as of now, cyazofamid remains a permitted and comparatively low-concern fungicide in integrated pest management programs.

Dimethomorph is a cinnamic acid derivative fungicide used to control Oomycete fungi (e.g., downy mildews and late blight). It is commonly used on potatoes, tomatoes, grapes, and vegetables in combination with a protectant partner (like mancozeb) for managing diseases like potato/tomato late blight (Phytophthora infestans) and grape downy mildew (Plasmopara viticola). Dimethomorph has translaminar and some systemic activity; it inhibits cell wall formation in target pathogens. Introduced in the 1990s, it became a key tool in integrated blight control programs. Often sold in pre-mixed products (e.g., with chlorothalonil or mancozeb) to broaden spectrum and prevent resistance.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary exposure from residues on treated crops (notably potatoes, tomatoes, lettuce, and grapes). Dimethomorph residues are frequently detected on these crops but typically below regulatory limits due to its use patterns and pre-harvest intervals.

Occupational exposure for mixers, loaders, and applicators (dermal and inhalation) when spraying dimethomorph, particularly since it is often applied in combination with other fungicides in wettable powder or liquid formulations.

By-stander or residential exposure is minimal; dimethomorph is used on commercial crops, not lawns or gardens. It is moderately persistent and can attach to soil particles, so minor environmental exposures via drift or runoff might occur but at low levels.

summary_sections.content: Dimethomorph has low acute toxicity (oral LD50 > 4000 mg/kg in rats) and is classified as unlikely to be a human carcinogen (animal studies showed no cancer increase). It is not mutagenic. In subchronic studies, high doses caused slight liver enlargement in rats but no significant adverse effects. Developmental and reproductive studies did not show teratogenic effects or fertility impairment at tested doses. Dimethomorph primarily raises concern for potential skin sensitization (in formulated products) and some mild irritation. It does not have a known endocrine-disrupting mode of action. The compound is metabolized and mostly excreted in feces (given its fat solubility) within days. Human biomonitoring data for dimethomorph are lacking, but given its low toxicity and moderate use, it’s not a priority compound for such studies. If present in blood or urine, it would reflect recent dietary intake of treated produce or acute occupational exposure; however, any such levels in consumers are expected to be far below any effect threshold. Overall, regulatory toxicological assessments have considered dimethomorph’s hazard profile to be relatively benign compared to older fungicides.

Dimethomorph is approved in the EU, US, and numerous countries. MRLs are established (e.g., in the EU: 0.05 mg/kg for potatoes, 2 mg/kg for grapes) and monitoring shows dimethomorph is one of the more frequently detected fungicide residues on produce, though generally within allowed levels. For instance, EFSA’s 2018 report noted dimethomorph on about 3% of samples, primarily lettuce and grapes, usually compliant with MRLs. The US PDP has also reported dimethomorph residues on potatoes and other vegetables, likewise at low concentrations. Regulatory agencies have set ADIs and acute reference doses with large safety factors due to its low toxicity, and current exposure estimates for consumers (including sensitive groups) are well below these limits. It is not included in any "highly hazardous" pesticide list given its profile. Resistance management and environmental impact (on aquatic species, for example) are the primary regulatory focus areas for dimethomorph rather than human health risk. It is not in NHANES or other biomonitoring surveys, reflecting its lower priority from a public health standpoint. Provided it’s used as directed (with protective measures for workers and adherence to pre-harvest intervals), dimethomorph continues to be considered a safe and effective fungicide in modern crop protection.

Ethirimol is a pyrimidinol fungicide historically used to control powdery mildew on turfgrass (especially for golf greens and lawns) and to a lesser extent on cereal crops. Introduced in the 1970s, it was one of the first systemic fungicides for turf. It specifically targets Erysiphe graminis (powdery mildew) by inhibiting fungal DNA synthesis. Ethirimol use was most common in the UK and Europe on sports turf and sometimes in barley fields as a mildewicide. Its importance waned with the advent of broader-spectrum and longer-residual fungicides.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Occupational/residential exposure on treated turf: groundskeepers or golfers could contact ethirimol on grass shortly after application (dermal exposure). During mixing and spraying on turf, applicators could inhale some spray mist or have skin contact if not using PPE.
Dietary exposure is practically zero; ethirimol was not significantly used on food crops in modern times (and any cereal use was decades ago and minor). Thus, it’s not found in the food supply.

Environmental exposure: ethirimol is moderately persistent and water-soluble, so there was some concern about leaching from treated turf into groundwater, but its limited use and rapid dilution meant minimal general population exposure.

summary_sections.content: Ethirimol has low acute toxicity (oral LD50 in rats > 5000 mg/kg). It has not been associated with significant chronic toxicity issues; no evidence of carcinogenicity, teratogenicity, or endocrine effects was noted in the limited data available from its era of registration. It is slightly irritative to eyes/skin in concentrated form but not a strong sensitizer. In the body, ethirimol is rapidly metabolized and excreted (primarily via urine). Given its targeted use and low toxicity, human health incidents from ethirimol were rarely reported. If someone were heavily exposed (e.g., a spill on skin), mild transient symptoms (like skin rash or slight nausea) might occur, but serious systemic effects are not expected at realistic exposure levels. Ethirimol is not included in current toxicology databases as a high-concern chemical; it predates many of the more rigorous testing requirements. Overall, it’s considered to have a favorable safety profile for humans, which partly explains why it was popularly used on playing surfaces (areas with potential public contact).

Ethirimol is no longer widely in use; in the EU it was not supported for re-registration and is considered obsolete. Other regions likewise phased it out as newer fungicides (like triazoles and strobilurins) took over. When it was in use, its regulatory status was relatively benign (no special restrictions beyond standard pesticide regulations). No specific residue tolerances were usually set for ethirimol on foods because its usage on edible crops was minimal. Environmental regulatory focus on ethirimol was limited to ensuring it didn’t contaminate water resources near golf courses; studies found that it could leach somewhat, but given its discontinued status, it’s not a present concern. Ethirimol doesn’t appear in environmental monitoring reports nowadays, nor in human biomonitoring. It’s mainly of historical interest. Current pesticide regulations are more stringent, and if ethirimol were evaluated today, it might require additional data, but its exit from the market precluded that. People who work in turf management now use different fungicides, and any legacy stocks of ethirimol (if they existed) would be long expired. Thus, regulatory and health discussions of ethirimol have largely sunset along with its commercial use, with the understanding that it was one of the lower-risk fungicides of its time.

Fenamidone is a QoI (quinone outside inhibitor) fungicide used to control downy mildews, late blight, and other Oomycete diseases on crops such as lettuce, onions, grapes, and potatoes. It was often used in rotation or mixture with other fungicides (like mancozeb) to manage resistance. Fenamidone acts by inhibiting mitochondrial respiration in fungi (complex III, similar to strobilurins). Introduced in the early 2000s, it offered broad-spectrum control of foliar diseases particularly in vegetables and was marketed under names like Reason®. Its use has been somewhat regional and it’s gradually been overshadowed by newer fungicides with more favorable profiles or residuals.
Major human exposure routes include:
bullets: Dietary intake from treated produce: fenamidone residues can occur on leafy vegetables, onions, or tubers treated close to harvest. Regulatory limits are set (e.g., a few ppm on lettuce) to ensure consumer safety and these are monitored.
