summary_sections.content: Low acute toxicity; liver and thyroid effects at high doses in animals are typical triazine endpoints. Blood detection reflects recent exposure; limited bioaccumulation.
EPA tolerances exist (40 CFR §180.213). Monitoring occurs via residue and water programs; not part of NHANES biomonitoring.
Secbumeton is a methoxytriazine herbicide used for pre-emergence control of broadleaf and grassy weeds in sugar beets and other crops.
Exposure is primarily dietary where used; worker dermal/inhalation exposure during application.
bullets: Ingestion of residues
Dermal/inhalation during field application

summary_sections.content: Low acute toxicity; liver/thyroid endpoints at high doses in animals. Blood detection indicates recent exposure; low bioaccumulation.
Not registered in the U.S.; EU approval withdrawn. U.S. monitoring would focus on residues in imports where relevant.
Simetryn is a triazine herbicide used mainly in rice and sugar cane for control of broadleaf weeds and some grasses.
Exposure in the U.S. is limited; where used, the main pathway is dietary; occupational exposure occurs during application.
bullets: Ingestion of residues (regions of use)
Dermal/inhalation for applicators

summary_sections.content: Low acute toxicity; liver/thyroid endpoints at high doses in animals. Blood detection indicates recent exposure.
Not registered in the U.S.; EU approvals withdrawn. Monitoring in the U.S. would be via import controls if applicable.
Terbumeton is a triazine herbicide formerly used for pre-emergence control of broadleaf weeds on various crops and non-crop areas.
Where used historically, public exposure would be dietary; worker exposure via dermal/inhalation during application.
bullets: Ingestion of residues (historic/limited use)
Dermal/inhalation for applicators

summary_sections.content: Low acute toxicity; liver/thyroid endpoints at high animal doses typical of triazines. Blood detection indicates recent exposure.
Not registered in the U.S.; EU approvals were withdrawn. U.S. monitoring would concern imported commodities if residues were possible.

Terbutryn is a selective s-triazine herbicide (methylthio-triazine class) that was used pre- and post-emergence to control broadleaf weeds and grasses in crops such as cereals, sorghum, sugarcane, and potatoes. It also found use in aquatic environments to suppress algae and submerged weeds in water bodies. Beyond agriculture, terbutryn has been used as a biocidal additive (preservative) in paints and coatings to prevent algal or fungal growth on surfaces.

Humans can be exposed to terbutryn mainly through environmental routes, as it is not used in consumer products. Because it was applied to crops and water, **ingestion** of food or drinking water is a possible pathway – residues were historically found in surface and groundwater near agricultural areas. **Inhalation** of spray mists or contaminated dust is another route for those near applications or using terbutryn (occupational exposure via aerosols and dust particles has been documented). **Dermal contact** can occur during handling of the herbicide or touching treated foliage, leading to absorption through the skin. Indoors, pesticides like terbutryn have even been detected as trace contaminants in house dust, suggesting that inhalation or ingestion of dust could provide low-level exposure in treated areas.
bullets: **Dietary ingestion** – consumption of crops or water contaminated with terbutryn residues (e.g. runoff into streams and wells near treated fields)
**Inhalation of aerosols/dust** – breathing in herbicide spray drift or dust particles, particularly by applicators or people nearby during spraying
**Skin contact** – direct dermal exposure when mixing or applying terbutryn or touching surfaces (soil, plants) recently treated with it
**Indoor dust** – incidental ingestion or inhalation of household dust that contains terbutryn tracked in from outside or released from treated materials

summary_sections.content: Detection of terbutryn in blood signifies recent exposure, as the compound does not bioaccumulate significantly. Animal studies show that terbutryn is rapidly metabolized and excreted – over 70% of an oral dose was eliminated within 24 hours in rats. At high doses, terbutryn affects the nervous system of test animals, causing symptoms like incoordination, labored breathing, and convulsions. Chronic toxicology research has raised concerns about endocrine disruption and carcinogenicity: terbutryn has induced thyroid and liver tumors in rodent studies, and it has been classified by the U.S. EPA as a Group C “possible human carcinogen”. It is also considered a potential endocrine disruptor based on screening assays. In general, the presence of terbutryn (parent or metabolites) in blood or urine indicates ongoing or recent exposure, not necessarily that it will cause harm at low levels, but it underscores that the individual has been in contact with this herbicide.

Terbutryn’s use has been heavily restricted due to health and environmental concerns. In the United States, many product registrations were voluntarily canceled and the EPA revoked tolerances for terbutryn residues on major food crops by the 1990s. It is no longer registered as an active pesticide in the U.S.. Terbutryn was also not approved under the EU’s pesticide regulation 1107/2009, with agricultural uses phased out in Europe by 2003. Globally, it is categorized by WHO as a Class III pesticide ("slightly hazardous") based on acute toxicity. Environmental monitoring programs track terbutryn in water and sediment (as it is moderately persistent), and it has appeared in national surveys of pesticides in dust and water. Overall, terbutryn is now either banned or highly regulated in most jurisdictions, and its presence in human biomonitoring studies is declining as its use has ceased.

Cyromazine is an insecticide of the triazine class that acts as an insect growth regulator (IGR). It is primarily used to target fly larvae and other dipteran pests. In veterinary and household settings, cyromazine is applied as a feed-through larvicide in poultry or livestock operations (added to animal feed or manure) to prevent fly breeding. It is also sprayed on crops (e.g. vegetables like cabbage, onions, peppers, tomatoes, and potatoes) to control leafminer and fly larvae infestations. Cyromazine’s selective action (disrupting insect development) makes it useful in integrated pest management for controlling pests on livestock (under trade names such as Larvadex) and field crops (e.g. Trigard for leafminers).

The general population may be exposed to cyromazine mainly through residues in food, whereas farm workers can be exposed during handling. **Dietary ingestion** of cyromazine can occur via consumption of treated commodities – for example, trace residues have been found in vegetables and in animal-derived products (meat, milk, eggs) from cyromazine-treated livestock. **Occupational inhalation and dermal contact** are relevant for agricultural workers: those mixing or applying cyromazine (spraying crops or distributing medicated feed) may inhale dust or spray aerosols and get the chemical on their skin. Cyromazine is highly water-soluble, so **drinking water contamination** is another possible route if runoff from treated fields enters wells or surface water. In indoor environments (farm buildings), particles containing cyromazine from feed or manure could be present in air or dust, leading to inhalation or inadvertent ingestion by workers. Overall, diet is the primary exposure pathway for the public, while farmers and applicators have additional inhalation and dermal exposure risks.
bullets: **Food ingestion** – eating produce (leafy vegetables, etc.) or animal products with residual cyromazine (permissible levels are regulated on foods)
**Drinking water** – in agricultural areas, cyromazine can leach or run off into water sources due to its high solubility, potentially contributing to low-level intake via water
**Inhalation for workers** – breathing in dust from treated animal feed/manure or spray mist when applying cyromazine on crops (farm occupational exposure)
**Skin contact** – handling cyromazine formulations, treated livestock bedding, or foliage can lead to dermal absorption if protective measures are inadequate

summary_sections.content: Cyromazine is considered to have low toxicity to mammals in acute exposures. In animal studies, it does not cause serious systemic effects at typical exposure levels; high doses can affect body weight and blood parameters (as noted by ACGIH). A notable aspect of cyromazine metabolism is its conversion to melamine (a chemical also known from other contexts) in animals. At very high doses in laboratory tests, melamine can induce bladder stones and tumors in rodents, but regulators have determined that these effects have a threshold far above any realistic human exposure from cyromazine residues. Thus, cyromazine has not been linked to carcinogenic or endocrine-disrupting outcomes in humans under normal use; it is classified by ACGIH as “not classifiable as a human carcinogen”. If cyromazine or its metabolite melamine is detected in human bio-samples, it typically indicates recent dietary or occupational exposure, given that the compound is not persistent in the body (it is readily excreted). Common biomarkers include measuring cyromazine or melamine in urine or blood to confirm exposure. Overall, cyromazine’s health profile in humans is relatively benign at low exposure, with safety margins built in by regulatory evaluations (e.g. JMPR established an Acceptable Daily Intake based on animal NOAELs).

Cyromazine is approved for use in many countries, including the U.S. and EU, with specific limits set for its residues in foods. The U.S. EPA and FDA have established tolerances for cyromazine on certain crops (leafy vegetables, mushrooms, etc.) and in livestock commodities; it has been registered as a feed-through larvicide and crop protection agent since the 1980s. Internationally, the Joint FAO/WHO Meeting on Pesticide Residues (JMPR) has evaluated cyromazine and determined that typical dietary exposure is well within safe margins. Cyromazine is subject to routine monitoring in food safety programs – for example, national pesticide residue surveys test for cyromazine in produce and animal products to ensure compliance with Maximum Residue Limits. In California, cyromazine is registered and listed as an active ingredient with ongoing registration status (not classified as a restricted material). Environmental monitoring may include checking water supplies in intensive farming areas, since the compound can appear in runoff. As for human biomonitoring, cyromazine itself is not commonly measured in population surveys, but its metabolite melamine is sometimes monitored as a surrogate. Overall, regulatory frameworks treat cyromazine as a relatively low-risk pesticide when used according to guidelines, and it remains available for agricultural use with periodic re-evaluation of its safety profile.

Ametryn is a herbicide belonging to the chlorotriazine family, chemically similar to atrazine. It is used to control broadleaf weeds and annual grasses in warm-climate crops. Major uses of ametryn have included applications on pineapple, sugarcane, bananas, corn, and certain citrus orchards. It can be applied pre-emergence or post-emergence to soils and foliage, where it inhibits photosynthesis in target weeds. Ametryn was introduced in the 1960s and was formulated as wettable powders and flowable liquids under trade names like Evik and Ametrex. Some combination products mixed ametryn with other herbicides (for example, with 2,4-D or atrazine) to broaden its spectrum. While effective in tropical agriculture (notably used in Hawaii on sugarcane and in Florida on citrus groves), ametryn’s use today is more limited as newer herbicides have supplemented it. It remains an option for weed control in certain regions for crops like sugarcane and root vegetables, where it controls pigweed, goosegrass, purslane and other common weeds.

For the general public, exposure to ametryn would mainly come from environmental residues, as it is an agricultural chemical. **Dietary exposure** can occur via trace residues on treated crops (e.g. on pineapples or other produce) and in drinking water. Ametryn is moderately persistent in soil and has been detected at low levels in surface and groundwater in farming regions; hence, rural well water could carry small amounts. **Occupational exposure** is a significant pathway for farmers and applicators: inhalation of spray mist or dust from ametryn formulations during mixing and spraying, and dermal contact while handling concentrated product or working in recently sprayed fields. Those in proximity to treated fields might also inhale drift. Because of ametryn’s chemical stability (soil half-life on the order of 70–250 days) and mobility, **drinking water ingestion** is a noted route – monitoring in the U.S. found ametryn in a few groundwater samples (up to 0.45 mg/L in some cases). **Dermal absorption** can happen if skin is unprotected during application, although ametryn is only slightly absorbed through skin (and is of low dermal toxicity). In summary, people most likely to be exposed are agricultural workers through inhalation and skin contact, whereas the general population’s exposure would come from consuming minute residues in food or water near use areas.
bullets: **Food and water ingestion** – consuming crops treated with ametryn or drinking water contaminated via field runoff (ametryn has been found in groundwater in farming areas)
**Inhalation (farm workers)** – breathing in spray aerosol or dust during herbicide application or from drift shortly after spraying
**Skin contact** – touching ametryn concentrates, spray solution, or foliage/soil that has recent ametryn deposits (common for mixers/loaders and applicators)
*(General public exposure to ametryn is low and sporadic, mostly limited to residues within regulatory limits on food or in water.)*

summary_sections.content: Ametryn is considered slightly toxic to humans and mammals. Acute poisoning is uncommon; at very high doses, test animals showed symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle weakness, and excess salivation. It is a mild irritant to the eyes, skin, and respiratory tract in its concentrated form. In sub-chronic and chronic studies, high doses of ametryn have been associated with liver effects – for example, prolonged feeding of large amounts led to liver weight changes and some evidence of liver damage in animals. There is no solid evidence of ametryn causing cancer or reproductive harm at environmental exposure levels: mutagenicity tests have mostly been negative (no significant DNA or gene mutations observed), and long-term studies did not show clear carcinogenicity (EPA has not classified ametryn as a human carcinogen due to insufficient data). Importantly, ametryn does not bioaccumulate; it is eliminated relatively quickly. In rats, over 90% of an administered dose was excreted (via urine and feces) within 72 hours, indicating that the compound and its metabolites do not persist in the body. Therefore, detection of ametryn in human blood or urine would imply a recent exposure. Overall, toxicity studies suggest a reasonable margin of safety at the low exposure levels typical for the general population. Nevertheless, as with other triazine herbicides, there is ongoing scrutiny for any endocrine-related effects, though none have been definitively observed for ametryn in current research.

Ametryn has been a General Use Pesticide (not restricted) in the United States, labeled with the EPA toxicity category III ("Caution") for its products. It was registered for use on various crops, with some state-specific allowances (for instance, Florida and Texas permitted its use in certain citrus and Bermuda grass situations). Over time, many of its uses have been reduced or phased out in favor of other herbicides. In the EU, ametryn is not approved under current pesticide regulations – its approval was withdrawn and it is no longer used on European crops. Countries that still allow ametryn maintain Maximum Residue Limits for food; for example, Codex Alimentarius has set residue limits for ametryn on crops like bananas and sugarcane. Environmental monitoring by agencies (like USGS and state departments) has occasionally included ametryn in water surveys; findings have generally been infrequent detections at very low concentrations. Regulatory agencies continue to monitor its presence: in the U.S., the EPA has conducted periodic re-registration reviews to ensure existing stocks or minor uses of ametryn do not pose undue risk. Because of its structural similarity to other triazines, ametryn’s regulatory status has often been evaluated alongside compounds like atrazine. Currently, ametryn use in the US is limited and it does not appear in national biomonitoring programs (e.g., it’s not part of CDC’s standard exposure report). It remains registered in a few countries for specific crops, but globally its usage and regulatory approvals have declined, reflecting caution due to environmental persistence and the availability of alternatives.

Sulfentrazone is a selective herbicide in the aryl triazolinone class (sometimes categorized as a phenyl triazolinone). It is a pre-emergent and early post-emergent herbicide used to control broadleaf weeds and sedges, with some activity on grasses. Sulfentrazone’s mode of action is inhibition of protoporphyrinogen oxidase (PPO), leading to membrane disruption in target plants (a “PPO inhibitor” herbicide). Introduced in the 1990s, it became widely used in soybean cultivation, as well as on tobacco, sunflowers, dry beans, and other crops. It is also employed in non-agricultural areas – for instance, for weed control on industrial sites, rights-of-way, and fallow fields. Trade names for sulfentrazone products include Authority®, Spartan®, and Dismiss® (the latter for turf use targeting sedges). The herbicide is often applied to soil before weeds emerge, providing residual control through root uptake. Its spectrum includes troublesome weeds like pigweed, lambsquarters, morning glory, waterhemp, and nutsedge. Sulfentrazone is valued for its long soil activity and has been integrated into conservation-tillage farming programs in the US. In summary, it is a modern broad-spectrum herbicide primarily for row crops (especially soybeans) and certain specialty uses, known for its effectiveness on tough broadleaf weeds and some grassy weeds.

For the general population, sulfentrazone exposure would mainly come from residues in food or water, whereas agricultural workers may experience direct contact. **Dietary ingestion** of minute residues can occur through foods grown in treated fields (e.g. soybeans or other crops – however, residue levels are typically low and regulated). **Drinking water** is a notable pathway: sulfentrazone is fairly mobile in soils and has a high leaching potential, so it can reach groundwater or runoff into surface water. Rural wells or surface water sources near application sites might contain trace amounts, especially given the herbicide’s persistence (it can be very persistent in soil and water under certain conditions). **Occupational exposure** (farmers, applicators) can happen via inhalation of dust from dry formulations or spray mist and via dermal contact when mixing, loading, or spraying – although sulfentrazone has low volatility, the handling of concentrates or contact with treated soil can transfer the chemical to skin. Those working in treated crop fields shortly after application might also absorb some sulfentrazone through the skin or by incidental ingestion (contact hand-to-mouth). **Runoff and drift** could, in theory, expose nearby residents through contaminated dust or droplets, but this is usually minimal. Overall, the major pathways are ingestion (food/water) for the public and combined dermal/inhalation for those applying the herbicide.
bullets: **Ingestion of residues** – consuming food crops that contain residual sulfentrazone (within regulatory limits) or drinking water impacted by agricultural runoff/leaching
**Inhalation (workers)** – breathing in aerosol droplets during spraying or dust from dry herbicide formulations (mostly affecting applicators and farm workers)
**Dermal contact** – skin exposure for workers handling the herbicide or touching recently treated plants/soil (sulfentrazone can adhere to skin or clothing during application)
*(General population exposure tends to be low; routine monitoring of produce and water helps ensure any sulfentrazone levels remain at safe levels.)*

summary_sections.content: Sulfentrazone has a relatively favorable acute toxicological profile – it is low in acute oral toxicity (EPA Toxicity Category III) and has not shown systemic toxicity at low exposure levels. In animal studies, sulfentrazone’s primary targets at higher doses include the liver and developmental processes. Some reproductive and developmental effects have been noted in laboratory animals (e.g. reduced fetal weight, skeletal variations) at doses above those causing maternal toxicity. These findings led regulators to consider sulfentrazone as having “possible developmental toxicity” at high exposure, though it is not considered a human teratogen at expected exposure levels. The compound has not been found to be mutagenic or genotoxic in standard tests. Chronic studies in rodents indicated no strong evidence of carcinogenicity; regulatory agencies have typically classified sulfentrazone as “not likely to be carcinogenic to humans” based on available data. Sulfentrazone is moderately persistent in the environment, but in the human body it does not bioaccumulate – it is metabolized and excreted relatively efficiently (primarily via urine). Biomonitoring data on sulfentrazone are limited; if detected in blood or urine, it would suggest recent agricultural exposure given its use pattern and excretion profile. Overall, health risk assessments (by EPA and others) have concluded that sulfentrazone’s presence at the low levels found in food or water is not expected to pose adverse health effects to the general population. Nonetheless, high-dose effects (on reproduction/development and blood chemistry) observed in animals inform safety margins and usage restrictions to protect vulnerable groups (such as pregnant women and children) with ample buffer.

Sulfentrazone was first registered in the U.S. in the mid-1990s, and it underwent EPA reregistration review in the 2000s. It is approved for use on a variety of crops (soybeans being the largest market) and subject to EPA-established tolerances (maximum residue limits) on those commodities. The EPA considers sulfentrazone a "reduced-risk" herbicide for some uses due to its low acute toxicity and environmental behavior, and it remains a widely registered active ingredient in the U.S. (including in combination products for pre-emergent weed control). In contrast, the European Union did not approve sulfentrazone under the older Directive 91/414/EEC – it has not been authorized for use on EU crops. (As of recent data, sulfentrazone is listed in the EU pesticide database but not approved for active use.) Other countries like Canada, Brazil, and Australia have registrations for sulfentrazone on certain crops, each with their own residue limits and environmental safeguards. Environmental monitoring programs keep an eye on sulfentrazone given its mobility: for instance, it has appeared on some U.S. state groundwater contaminant candidate lists because of its leaching potential. However, national water surveys (USGS NAWQA) have generally found infrequent detections of sulfentrazone in surface or groundwater. Sulfentrazone is not part of routine human biomonitoring surveys (such as CDC’s NHANES), likely because general population exposure is very low. Regulatory agencies continue to monitor any new health or ecological data; to date, sulfentrazone has been re-confirmed as eligible for use in the U.S. with certain label restrictions (e.g. buffer zones to protect water and aquatic life). In summary, sulfentrazone is a regulated herbicide with ongoing approval in the U.S. and many countries, whereas some jurisdictions (like the EU) opted not to authorize it, partly out of precaution for its environmental persistence.

Chloroxuron is an older phenylurea herbicide (specifically a diphenylurea) that was formerly used as a selective weed killer. It was introduced in the 1960s and used pre- and early post-emergence to control annual grasses, broadleaf weeds, and even mosses in various crops. Major applications included soybeans, vegetables (like carrots, onions, peas), strawberries, fruit orchards, ornamental plantings, and conifer plantations. Chloroxuron acts by inhibiting photosynthesis in target plants. It was sold under trade names such as Tenoran and Norex and often applied to soil before weed seeds germinated. Additionally, chloroxuron found some use in turf and non-crop areas for moss control. However, chloroxuron is now considered an obsolete pesticide. The primary manufacturer (Ciba-Geigy) discontinued its production prior to the mid-1990s, and it is no longer registered for active use in most countries. In summary, chloroxuron was once a moderately broad-spectrum herbicide for crops and turf, but its use has been phased out in favor of newer herbicides with improved safety and efficacy.

Current exposure to chloroxuron is expected to be minimal for the general population, given that it is no longer in use. Historically, **dietary exposure** could have occurred by consuming treated crops (like soybeans or vegetables) with chloroxuron residues. **Drinking water** in agricultural regions might have had low levels due to field runoff, as chloroxuron is moderately persistent in soil (field half-life on the order of weeks to a few months) and not highly prone to leaching. In the past, **occupational exposure** affected farmers and greenhouse workers who mixed or sprayed chloroxuron – they could inhale dust from formulations or spray droplets and have dermal contact during application. If any stocks of chloroxuron remained in use (or in storage), those handling it could still be exposed via these routes. Because chloroxuron was an odorless, colorless solid often formulated as a wettable powder, **inhalation of powder dust** was a potential pathway for workers. **Dermal absorption** is possible but the compound has low dermal toxicity, and protective equipment would mitigate this. Today, any residual exposure would likely come from environmental remnants: for example, residues in soil of previously treated sites (though after decades, significant residues are unlikely), or minor contamination of groundwater at old sites. Overall, with chloroxuron’s use discontinued, the pathways of exposure have largely been eliminated, and any ongoing exposure would be very limited and localized.
bullets: **Food ingestion (historical)** – eating crops that were sprayed with chloroxuron (e.g. leafy vegetables, strawberries), though usage on edible crops has long been discontinued
**Water ingestion** – drinking water from wells or streams near sites formerly treated (chloroxuron is moderately persistent but not highly water-soluble, so water contamination was low)
**Occupational inhalation** – breathing in dust from chloroxuron powder or spray mists during mixing and applying (relevant to past farm or greenhouse workers)
**Dermal contact** – skin exposure while handling chloroxuron concentrate or working in recently treated fields (could occur without proper gloves/protection in the past)

summary_sections.content: Chloroxuron is of low to moderate toxicity in mammals. In animal feeding studies, urea-type herbicides like chloroxuron generally showed low chronic toxicity. Chloroxuron’s acute toxicity is low – for example, it has relatively high LD50 values (indicating only mild toxicity if ingested in large amounts) and it was not known to be a strong skin irritant or sensitizer. Some unique toxicological observations: chloroxuron can form a minor contaminant (dimethylnitrosamine) under certain conditions, which is a carcinogen. While chloroxuron itself was not clearly linked to cancer in animals, the nitrosamine impurity raised concerns about potential carcinogenic risk if present. High doses of chloroxuron in laboratory animals have been associated with methemoglobinemia – the compound (or its metabolites) can induce formation of methemoglobin, reducing blood’s oxygen-carrying capacity. This effect and central nervous system depression were noted in extreme overdose scenarios (far above any environmental exposure). In practical use, such effects were unlikely because exposures were much lower. No significant reproductive or developmental effects have been documented for chloroxuron. If chloroxuron were detected in human blood, it would indicate an unusual exposure event, given its discontinued status. In the past, manufacturing workers or formulators might have had measurable levels, but nowadays the compound is rarely encountered. Overall, chloroxuron’s known health effects (e.g. mild blood changes at high doses, irritation on contact) are manageable, but the compound was phased out in part due to potential long-term risks like nitrosamine formation and the availability of safer alternatives.

Chloroxuron is no longer registered as a pesticide in major markets. In the United States, it was never a widely used herbicide and all product registrations were eventually canceled (by the 1990s) as the manufacturer withdrew support. The U.S. EPA does not include chloroxuron in current tolerance (maximum residue) regulations, meaning it is not approved for use on food crops. In the European Union, chloroxuron is listed as “not approved” under regulation – any earlier approvals lapsed and it is not on the market. According to the PPDB database, chloroxuron had its EU approval expire and it is not permitted in any member state. Notably, the manufacturer (Ciba-Geigy) discontinued chloroxuron production before 1994, effectively removing it from commerce globally. Because of this, monitoring of chloroxuron in the environment or food has largely ceased; it is not part of routine pesticide residue surveillance programs today. During its time of use, some countries had set residue limits (e.g. tolerances on soybeans or other crops), but those have been revoked. Chloroxuron is also absent from modern biomonitoring endeavors (like NHANES) due to its obsolescence. One regulatory consideration historically was the formation of nitrosamine impurities – regulators had imposed manufacturing practice changes to minimize that risk. Currently, chloroxuron might appear only as a reference in archives or pollutant lists but with no active regulatory measures since it is essentially banned worldwide. In summary, chloroxuron’s regulatory status is “canceled/not approved” across jurisdictions, and it is no longer subject to active monitoring except perhaps in contaminated site investigations.

Chlortoluron (also known as chlorotoluron) is a phenylurea herbicide used to control broadleaf weeds and annual grasses, particularly in cereal crops. It acts as a residual, systemic herbicide, inhibiting photosynthesis in susceptible plants. First introduced in the 1970s, chlortoluron became a common herbicide in Europe for winter wheat and barley fields, where it targets weeds such as annual meadow grass, blackgrass, chickweed, and poppy. It can be applied to soil or post-emergence on crops and has both contact and residual activity. In addition to cereals, chlortoluron has been used (often in mixtures) on crops like potatoes, carrots, and some fruit orchards to control a wide spectrum of weeds. Formulations were sold under names like Dicurane and Toluron (CTU) and were generally applied in the autumn or early spring. Chlortoluron is somewhat volatile and moderately water-soluble, which gave it a tendency to move in soil and reach weed root zones. In practice, it was valued for its weed control efficacy in cool-season cereals. However, due to regulatory changes and weed resistance issues, chlortoluron’s usage has declined and in some areas has been phased out. As of the mid-2010s, it remained approved in a few countries (with restrictions) for cereal crop use, but has been banned in others.

The primary exposure route for chlortoluron in the general population is through trace residues on food commodities, since it was chiefly used on food crops like wheat. **Dietary ingestion** of minute amounts could occur via consumption of products made from treated grain (though processing reduces residues) or from root crops if they were treated. Chlortoluron is moderately persistent and can leach, so **drinking water** in agricultural regions is another possible pathway – in areas of heavy use, it was occasionally detected in groundwater or streams (leading the EU to monitor it under the Water Framework Directive). **Occupational exposure** applies to farm workers and applicators: inhalation of spray mist or dust (if handling dry formulations) and dermal contact during mixing, loading, or spraying are relevant routes. Chlortoluron has low volatility, but **spray drift** could expose nearby residents or bystanders to small airborne concentrations. Once applied, the compound can remain in soils for weeks; thus, **dermal contact with soil** (for example, by workers re-entering fields without protection) could result in minor absorption. In indoor settings, chlortoluron is not a concern (not used in homes), but **take-home contamination** – trace residues on clothing or equipment – could bring some into domestic environments of farm families. Overall, those with the highest potential exposure were cereal crop farmers through inhalation and skin contact, whereas general population exposure was low and primarily via diet and environment (drinking water). With many countries halting chlortoluron use, these exposure pathways have been largely abated.
bullets: **Food consumption** – eating grains or vegetables from fields treated with chlortoluron (residues are generally low; monitoring ensures they stay under legal limits)
**Contaminated water** – drinking well water or surface water in farming areas where chlortoluron was used (it has been found in some water sources in past monitoring)
**Occupational inhalation** – breathing in herbicide spray or dust during application (cereal farmers, sprayer operators)
**Dermal exposure** – skin contact with chlortoluron concentrate or treated foliage/soil (if protective gear is inadequate during or after spraying)

summary_sections.content: Chlortoluron is classified as moderately toxic to mammals. Acute exposure can cause slight symptoms; it is not highly acutely poisonous (oral LD50 in rats is a few hundred to a thousand mg/kg, indicating low acute toxicity). It can irritate the eyes and skin with direct contact but is not a strong sensitizer. Toxicologically, chlortoluron has drawn attention for potential chronic effects. Studies in rodents have shown that high doses over long periods can lead to an increased incidence of benign testicular tumors and liver enzyme changes. This has raised suspicions of endocrine-related activity; indeed, some research suggests chlortoluron might act as an endocrine disruptor (affecting hormone-regulated processes in animals). Because of these findings, regulatory bodies consider chlortoluron as a possible human carcinogen and endocrine disruptor, though definitive human data are lacking. In fact, the compound was identified as meeting two "Persistent, Bioaccumulative, Toxic" criteria in the EU, partly on these grounds. Chlortoluron does not bioaccumulate significantly in human tissue; animal metabolism studies show it is broken down and excreted rather than stored. Therefore, detection of chlortoluron or its metabolites in human blood or urine would reflect recent exposure. It has occasionally been monitored in farmers (urine samples) where use was common. Health surveillance of workers did not reveal acute illnesses from chlortoluron, but precautionary principle measures have been applied due to the long-term cancer and reproductive toxicity concerns. In California, for example, chlortoluron is not listed under Proposition 65 (unlike linuron), but the mechanistic similarities among phenylureas keep it on toxicologists’ radar. In summary, chlortoluron’s health profile includes low acute toxicity but potential chronic hazards (tumors, endocrine effects) at high exposure levels, which contributed to its regulatory curtailment.

Chlortoluron’s regulatory history reflects growing health and environmental caution. In the European Union, it was approved as an active substance in the past but became a candidate for substitution due to concerns (persistence and bioaccumulative potential). Several EU countries restricted or did not support its re-registration, and by 2020 chlortoluron was largely phased out in the EU (with its approval scheduled to expire in 2026 and not likely renewed). Some member states had maintained interim authorizations for use in cereals under strict conditions, but many have revoked products containing chlortoluron. The EU has also monitored chlortoluron as a water contaminant; it appears on certain water quality watch lists because it was detected in groundwater above 0.1 μg/L in some surveys. In the United States, chlortoluron was never widely registered; it does not appear in EPA’s current database of approved pesticide active ingredients (no food tolerances exist for it in the U.S.), effectively meaning it’s not used on U.S. crops. Internationally, a few countries outside Europe may still allow chlortoluron on cereals, but its usage is declining globally. Regulatory agencies like Health Canada have no registered products for chlortoluron at present. Because of its diminishing use, routine residue monitoring for chlortoluron in food has become uncommon (it might be included in multi-residue analytical methods but is seldom detected). In occupational safety regulations, where it was used, exposure limits like TLVs were not specifically set for chlortoluron; general pesticide handling standards applied. With the trend toward more benign herbicides and concern over chlortoluron’s hazard profile, its regulatory status in most regions now is “not approved” or “severely restricted,” and it is effectively out of circulation in agriculture. Environmental monitoring data (from the era of use) have been archived to inform risk assessments for any structurally similar compounds that remain in use.

Fluometuron is a substituted phenylurea herbicide primarily used in cotton production. It is a selective, soil-applied herbicide that controls annual grasses and broadleaf weeds by inhibiting photosynthesis in those plants. First registered in the 1970s, fluometuron became a standard herbicide in cotton-growing regions (particularly in the United States) due to its effectiveness on weeds like pigweed, lambsquarters, and annual morning glory. It is usually applied pre-emergence (to the soil after planting but before crop emergence) or early post-emergence. Fluometuron formulations have included wettable powders and flowable liquids under trade names such as Cotoran® and Metauron. Besides cotton, it has had limited use on crops like sugarcane and some vegetable crops, but cotton remains its primary use case. The herbicide has a relatively long soil residual activity, helping to suppress weed growth through much of the growing season. It tends to be stable in soil and can leach under certain conditions, which has been a consideration for its environmental management. In summary, fluometuron is known as a cotton herbicide, valued for broad-spectrum control of weeds in that crop, and has been used in cotton farming for decades (though usage has decreased in some areas due to newer herbicides and transgenic herbicide-tolerant crops).

The most relevant exposure to fluometuron for the general public is through the environment (water) and food, whereas occupational exposure concerns those who handle the herbicide. **Dietary exposure** is usually low; cotton is not a direct food (except cottonseed by-products), but fluometuron can end up at trace levels in rotational food crops or in regional water supplies. **Drinking water ingestion** is a potential pathway: fluometuron has high leachability and has been classified as mobile in soil, meaning it can reach groundwater or runoff to surface water. Indeed, monitoring has occasionally detected fluometuron in agricultural runoff and drainage water in cotton-growing areas. Thus, rural well water or streams near cotton fields might contain low concentrations, which if consumed could expose individuals. **Occupational exposure** includes inhalation and dermal contact for farmers and applicators mixing or spraying fluometuron. Inhalation of dust from formulations (e.g., if using a powdered concentrate) or mist from spraying can occur, though wearing masks and enclosed cab tractors mitigate this. Skin exposure can occur when handling the herbicide or touching treated soil (fluometuron residues on soil particles can adhere to skin or clothing). **Surface water recreation** (like swimming in farm ditches or ponds near cotton fields) could be a very minor route of exposure via skin or incidental ingestion, but this is not common. Because fluometuron is stable and persists in soil and sediments, there is a possibility of long-term low-level presence in certain environments, but generally exposure is localized. The compound is not volatile (low vapor pressure), so inhalation of vapors is not a concern – inhalation would only be of spray droplets or dust. Overall, key pathways are drinking water (for the public in cotton regions) and on-field exposure for workers; with regulated application practices, these exposure routes are kept within safety margins.
bullets: **Contaminated water ingestion** – drinking groundwater or surface water impacted by fluometuron runoff/leaching from cotton fields (monitoring shows it can appear in farm-area water)
**Occupational inhalation** – breathing in herbicide mist or dust during spraying or mixing (affecting cotton farmers, applicators)
**Dermal contact** – skin exposure for workers handling concentrates or working in freshly treated fields (fluometuron can remain on soil/dust that contacts skin)

**Food chain** – generally minimal, but possibly through consumption of crops grown in rotation after cotton (if soil residues uptake into those crops) or via cottonseed oil/feed residues (indirectly entering human food as trace components)

summary_sections.content: Fluometuron has low to moderate toxicity in mammals. It is not acutely highly toxic; for instance, it has an oral LD50 in rats typically in the hundreds of mg/kg, classifying it as slightly toxic. It also has low volatility, so it poses little inhalation hazard aside from particulate exposure. A notable toxicological concern identified in studies is its potential effect on development and reproduction at higher doses: regulatory data indicate that fluometuron caused developmental delays and fetal effects in test animals, which is why it carries a high-alert flag for reproduction/developmental toxicity. These effects were observed at doses above those causing maternal toxicity, suggesting a threshold far above typical exposure. There is no strong evidence that fluometuron is carcinogenic. Long-term feeding studies in rodents did not show a clear carcinogenic response, and it has not been classified as such by EPA (it was considered not genotoxic and not likely to be carcinogenic at environmental exposure levels). Fluometuron’s detection in blood or urine would point to recent exposure (since like other phenylureas it doesn’t bioaccumulate significantly). It is metabolized in the liver; animal studies indicate that fluometuron is broken down and excreted rather than stored (small residues can be found in fat or organs if exposure is continuous, but they diminish after exposure stops). In humans, no specific poisoning syndromes are attributed to fluometuron, though high acute exposures might cause symptoms like methemoglobinemia or CNS depression analogous to other urea herbicides (this is extrapolated from structurally related compounds and high-dose animal data). From a health monitoring standpoint, the EPA and other agencies set an Acceptable Daily Intake (ADI) and reference doses that incorporate the developmental findings to ensure wide margins of safety. In cotton farming communities, no unusual illness patterns have been linked to fluometuron use, and it’s generally regarded as posing low risk when used properly. Nonetheless, due to the developmental toxicity signals and persistence, it is monitored and has been flagged as a “candidate for substitution” in some jurisdictions requiring safer alternatives to be considered.

Fluometuron has been widely registered for use on cotton in the United States since 1974. The EPA has set residue tolerances for fluometuron on cotton commodities (e.g., cottonseed) and a few other crops. In EPA’s regulatory framework, fluometuron passed re-registration eligibility in the 2000s with certain label requirements (such as groundwater advisory statements due to its leaching potential). It is classified as a “Group E – evidence of non-carcinogenicity for humans” by EPA, indicating no evidence of cancer risk in tests. However, the EPA did identify the need to protect groundwater; some states (like Florida or California) have listed fluometuron as a potential groundwater contaminant and monitor its presence in vulnerable aquifers. In the European Union, fluometuron has been approved under EU pesticide regulations and was included in Annex I (with Spain and Belgium as reporting countries). Its current approval in the EU is set to expire in 2026, and it has been flagged as a candidate for substitution due to concerns like a low Acceptable Daily Intake (ADI) and potential endocrine disruption. This means EU regulators will reassess whether to renew its approval. Fluometuron has appeared on some EU member state monitoring programs for water quality. For example, trace levels have been detected in runoff water in the Mississippi Delta and in drainage from Australian cotton fields, informing guidelines to mitigate water contamination. In terms of biomonitoring, fluometuron itself hasn’t been a target analyte in national exposure reports, given it’s used mostly on a non-food crop. Nonetheless, organizations ensure that any residues in food (from crop rotation or feed) remain below set limits. In summary, fluometuron remains a regulated cotton herbicide with active registrations in the US and some other countries, but it faces ongoing scrutiny. Authorities in both the US and EU require periodic review of its safety data; pending those reviews, its regulatory status could change if concerns outweigh its agricultural benefits. Currently, it is still permitted but with classification as a pesticide requiring risk mitigation (hence its listing as an EU candidate for substitution and monitoring of water sources).

Linuron is a substituted urea herbicide that has been widely used for decades to control weeds in both crop and non-crop settings. It is a selective systemic herbicide applied pre- or post-emergence to inhibit the growth of annual grasses and broadleaf weeds. Linuron was commonly used on crops such as soybeans, carrots, parsnips, potatoes, asparagus, corn, cereals, and certain fruit orchards. It is absorbed mainly through plant roots (from soil application) and also through leaves if sprayed post-emergence. Some trade names for linuron products included Lorox® and Linex®. Beyond food crops, linuron found use in non-crop areas like industrial sites and along railways to control vegetation. The herbicide’s mode of action is photosynthetic inhibition in susceptible plants. Because of its broad spectrum and residual activity (lasting a couple of months in soil), linuron was a popular herbicide in vegetable farming and row crops through the 1970s–1990s. In recent years, however, its use has declined due to regulatory restrictions and the availability of newer herbicides. For example, the European Union banned linuron in 2017, and some alternatives (like metribuzin or glyphosate-resistant crop systems) have replaced it. Nonetheless, historically linuron was an important herbicide in weed management, known for controlling weeds like pigweed, lamb’s quarters, and shepherd’s purse in various crops.

Linuron exposure for the general population primarily comes through residues in food and possibly contaminated water, while for those who handled linuron (e.g. farmers), dermal and inhalation routes were relevant. **Dietary ingestion** can occur via consuming produce from fields treated with linuron. Regulatory monitoring historically found low residues on some root vegetables and cereals, though typically within safety limits. Linuron degrades moderately in soil but some portion can be taken up by succeeding crops; thus diet was a main route. **Drinking water** is another pathway: linuron is moderately persistent and somewhat mobile (field half-life ~60 days). It has been detected at very low concentrations in groundwater and wells in farming regions (for instance, trace linuron was found in a few U.S. states’ groundwater samples). People using shallow wells near treated fields could ingest small amounts. **Occupational exposure** was significant for applicators and farm workers: inhalation of dust or spray mist when mixing or spraying linuron formulations (often wettable powders) and skin contact during handling or from drift. Linuron is not very volatile, so vapor inhalation was negligible, but **aerosol/dust inhalation** and **dermal absorption** were key routes on the job. Studies have indicated that linuron does not bioaccumulate, so any absorption is usually excreted, meaning blood/urine levels would reflect recent exposures. **Indoor exposure** for the general public would be rare, since linuron wasn’t used indoors. However, a minor pathway could be **household dust** in agricultural homes – families of pesticide applicators might have had residues brought in on clothing or equipment. In summary, ingestion (food/water) was the main route for the general population, whereas inhalation and skin contact during application were the main routes for those who used linuron in the field.
bullets: **Food consumption** – eating crops (vegetables, grains) that carried linuron residues from pre-harvest treatments
**Water ingestion** – drinking water from sources (wells, surface water) near areas where linuron was heavily used, as it can leach into groundwater
**Inhalation (occupational)** – breathing in spray droplets or dust during mixing/loading of linuron or while spraying fields (especially with older equipment lacking closed cabs)
**Skin contact** – exposure through skin when handling linuron concentrate, repairing clogged nozzles, or walking through recently treated fields without protective gear

summary_sections.content: Linuron has been scrutinized for potential chronic health effects. Acutely, it is of relatively low toxicity – it’s classified in EPA Toxicity Category III (slightly toxic). High single exposures can cause mild symptoms (it is a slight skin and eye irritant and can cause methemoglobinemia at very large doses, affecting oxygen transport in blood). The bigger concern is chronic exposure: animal studies have shown that linuron can affect endocrine function and reproductive development. Notably, long-term studies in rats and mice found an increased incidence of benign testicular tumors and effects on male reproductive organs at high dose levels. Linuron is known to act as an anti-androgen in mammals – it can block or reduce the action of male hormones, leading to reproductive and developmental effects (e.g., reduced fetal weight, delays in male offspring reproductive development in lab animals). These findings prompted regulatory bodies to regard linuron as an endocrine-disrupting chemical. California’s Proposition 65, for example, lists linuron as a chemical “known to cause developmental toxicity” (based on authoritative body findings). In mutagenicity and genotoxicity tests, linuron mostly tested negative, suggesting it is not a strong DNA-damaging agent. Carcinogenicity evaluations in animals did show some tumor formation (testes and liver), but the data weren’t clear-cut enough to classify it as a definitive human carcinogen – EPA initially did not assign it a formal carcinogen category, though the tumor findings contribute to its risk profile. Linuron is metabolized and excreted relatively quickly, breaking down into 3,4-dichloroaniline and other metabolites; these metabolites are less toxic than linuron itself. Human biomonitoring studies (e.g., of farmers) have detected linuron or its breakdown products in urine, indicating exposure, but these levels were low. The implication of detecting linuron in blood/urine is that an individual has been recently exposed – likely through work or diet – and chronic presence could hint at ongoing exposure. In terms of health protection, the awareness of linuron’s endocrine activity led to tighter regulations and the eventual banning in the EU to prevent any long-term risks to consumers or the environment. People acutely poisoned by linuron (a rare event) might exhibit symptoms like weakness, apathy, or cyanosis (from methemoglobinemia), which would be managed by medical professionals. Overall, linuron is considered to pose minimal acute risk but has notable chronic toxicological concerns (hormonal and reproductive effects) at sustained high exposures, which guided its phase-out in many regions.

Linuron’s regulatory status has changed significantly in recent years. In the United States, linuron was registered and used since the 1960s; EPA set tolerances for residues on various crops (e.g. 0.5 ppm on carrots, 1.0 ppm on potatoes, etc.). However, concerns over its risks led to a voluntary cancellation of many linuron uses by the registrant. As of 2017, the primary U.S. manufacturer withdrew linuron products, and linuron is no longer in widespread use domestically. It was never classified as a restricted-use pesticide federally (it was general use), but state regulators imposed extra precautions due to groundwater concerns in places like Wisconsin. In the European Union, linuron was withdrawn from approval in 2017 – the EU voted not to renew linuron’s approval because of its toxicological profile (classified as toxic for reproduction category 2 and concerns about endocrine disruption). All linuron-containing products in EU member states had to be phased out by 2018. Canada followed suit, discontinuing linuron registration around the same time. Given these bans, many monitoring programs have been looking for linuron’s alternatives; for instance, regulatory agencies promoted other herbicides or integrated weed management in carrots and other affected crops. **Monitoring**: Prior to its phase-out, linuron was part of pesticide residue monitoring in produce, and it occasionally was detected in water monitoring programs. For example, EU Water Framework surveillance listed linuron as a priority substance, requiring member states to monitor it in water bodies. Some legacy monitoring continues, as linuron’s stable metabolite 3,4-dichloroaniline can persist in soil and water. **Biomonitoring**: Linuron itself has not been a standard analyte in CDC’s exposure report, but research studies on occupational exposure (e.g., farm family studies) measured linuron in urine in the past. With regulatory bans, exposure levels have likely dropped, and linuron is not expected to be found in current general population biomonitoring. Regulatory agencies like California’s OEHHA have listed linuron under Prop 65 (developmental toxicity) which mandates warnings if it were present in consumer products (though it’s not in consumer products directly). Any remaining stocks of linuron are subject to disposal or limited use permits. In summary, linuron has moved from a once-common herbicide to a largely disallowed substance due to health/environment concerns. Ongoing regulatory focus is on ensuring it’s not contaminating food or water from past use – for instance, checking that produce from fields that used linuron in the past meets safety standards (which it has, due to degradation over time). The transition away from linuron is often cited as a case where a pesticide’s suspected endocrine disruption led to preventive regulatory action.

Methabenzthiazuron is a herbicide belonging to the benzothiazole-substituted urea class. It was used to control a broad spectrum of weeds (both grasses and broadleaves) in crops like cereals (wheat, barley), legumes, and some root vegetables. Typically applied pre-emergence, methabenzthiazuron works by inhibiting photosynthetic electron transport in susceptible plants. It was introduced in the late 1960s by Bayer (Ref. BAY 74283) and sold under names like Tribunil. The herbicide was valued for its soil residual action, providing weeks of weed suppression after application. Example target weeds included blackgrass, wild oats, chickweed, and other common annuals in cereal fields. Some use occurred in onion and garlic fields as well. Methabenzthiazuron is absorbed through roots and shoots of weeds. While effective in its day, this herbicide is now considered obsolete. It is no longer widely produced – the primary manufacturer discontinued it before the mid-1990s, and it never gained as much popularity as related urea herbicides (like diuron or linuron). In summary, methabenzthiazuron was a selective herbicide for various crops, particularly small grains and some vegetables, but it saw its use decline and is now phased out in most markets.

Given that methabenzthiazuron is no longer in active use, current exposure opportunities are minimal. Historically, **dietary exposure** could have occurred through consumption of treated crops, but since the compound was mainly used on cereals and some vegetables, any residues would typically be removed by food processing (for cereals) or were low on harvested produce. **Drinking water** exposure was possible in areas where it was heavily used – methabenzthiazuron is fairly persistent (noted as "persistent" in soil), so it could linger in soil and potentially leach or run off. However, its usage was not as extensive as other herbicides, so it was infrequently detected in water monitoring. **Occupational exposure** was relevant when it was marketed: farm workers might inhale spray mist or dust from formulations and get skin contact during mixing and application. Like many urea herbicides, methabenzthiazuron has low vapor pressure, so inhalation would mainly be of aerosols, not fumes. **Dermal absorption** could occur if workers handled the wettable powder or liquid without gloves or if they were in recently sprayed fields. For the general public, **indoor exposure** or household dust routes are negligible because it was not used around homes. If any existing stocks were improperly stored, those in proximity could have exposure, but such scenarios are rare. In essence, at present, exposure pathways for methabenzthiazuron are largely historical or theoretical: individuals could have been exposed via diet or water in the past, and applicators via inhalation/skin, but with its discontinuation, significant exposure today is unlikely. Environmental residues, if any persist in soil, would be localized and expected to degrade over time (though noted as persistent, it eventually breaks down through microbial action).
bullets: **Food ingestion** – eating crops (grain products, vegetables) that in the past were treated with methabenzthiazuron (residues generally low and now moot due to discontinued use)
**Water ingestion** – drinking from water sources near historically treated fields; persistent soil residues could have leached, but limited usage made this uncommon
**Occupational inhalation & skin contact** – (historical) exposure of farmers via breathing spray mist or dust and skin exposure when applying or handling the herbicide
*(Currently, exposure pathways are negligible as methabenzthiazuron is no longer approved or used.)*

summary_sections.content: Methabenzthiazuron is characterized by low acute toxicity. It was not associated with severe acute poisoning in humans or animals during its period of use; the LD50 in rats is relatively high (indicating low toxicity), and it did not strongly irritate skin or eyes. The compound is considered to have low mammalian toxicity overall. Data gaps exist for many chronic endpoints due to its age and limited use – there were "significant data missing" flags in databases, which suggests incomplete toxicological profiling. From analogous urea herbicides, one might infer some potential for effects like methemoglobinemia or thyroid effects at high doses, but specific chronic studies for methabenzthiazuron aren’t well-publicized. It was not flagged as a carcinogen or endocrine disruptor in the available literature, and short-term tests did not show alarming results. The PPDB hazard summary for methabenzthiazuron showed no alerts for human health (only a Low alert), implying no known significant health issues. Thus, detection of methabenzthiazuron in human samples would simply indicate exposure; there’s no known biomarker effect (like a specific enzyme inhibition or hormone change) associated with it. The body likely metabolizes and excretes it similar to other urea herbicides (which are usually excreted in urine as more water-soluble metabolites). In practical terms, since exposure now is negligible, the health risk today is essentially nil. During its use, standard pesticide precautions (avoiding direct contact, etc.) were deemed sufficient to protect applicators. No reports of widespread illness from methabenzthiazuron were documented. Overall, from the toxicological information available, methabenzthiazuron posed relatively low hazard to human health, which is consistent with its classification as a general use herbicide. Its discontinuation was more due to market factors and regulatory streamlining (and perhaps environmental persistence) rather than specific human health dangers.

Methabenzthiazuron is no longer an approved pesticide in the US, EU, or most other jurisdictions. It was never a high-profile herbicide compared to others in its class. In the EU, methabenzthiazuron was not included in Annex I when pesticide directives were updated; any product authorizations expired long ago (it is listed as "not approved" under EU Reg. 1107/2009, with approval status marked as expired). Similarly, the US EPA does not have any active registrations for methabenzthiazuron today. The primary manufacturer (Bayer) stopped selling it by the 1990s, and without support for reregistration, it fell off the market. As a result, regulatory focus on methabenzthiazuron has been minimal in recent decades – it’s essentially an obsolete compound. It’s not included in current pesticide residue monitoring programs (e.g., USDA’s Pesticide Data Program doesn’t test for it, because it’s not used). Environmental monitoring for methabenzthiazuron is also virtually nonexistent now, aside from perhaps historical research studies on persistence. During its time of use, some countries may have set MRLs (Maximum Residue Limits) for methabenzthiazuron on certain crops, but those would have been revoked after its use ended. One noteworthy regulatory note: because methabenzthiazuron was persistent in soil (the PPDB flags it as "High alert: Persistent" in environmental fate), there were considerations about long-term soil buildup; however, with cessation of use, that concern abated. Monitoring would now be limited to possibly checking old stock disposal or contaminated site assessments, if any. In summary, methabenzthiazuron currently has no active regulatory status (it’s effectively banned or unregistered everywhere). It’s absent from modern pesticide lists and thus from routine monitoring. Regulatory agencies did not need to take special action to ban it for health reasons; it more so lapsed due to lack of support and the availability of other herbicides. Therefore, it stands as a discontinued chemical, and regulatory efforts are focused on its replacements or ensuring any lingering residues from the past do not pose issues (which, given its last uses were decades ago, they generally do not).

Metobromuron is a phenylurea herbicide used for pre-emergence control of broadleaf and grass weeds. Chemically, it is closely related to monolinuron and diuron, with a bromine-substituted phenyl ring. Historically, metobromuron was used in crops like potatoes, sunflowers, soybeans, tomatoes, and tobacco to manage annual weeds before or shortly after they sprout. It acts by inhibiting photosynthesis in weeds. One notable use was as a replacement in some instances for linuron or monolinuron; for example, modern potato herbicide formulations (such as *Praxim*, containing metobromuron) have been introduced in Europe after linuron’s ban. Metobromuron provides residual soil activity for a few weeks, suppressing weeds such as lambsquarters, black bindweed, foxtails, and other common broadleaves and grasses. It is usually applied to the soil surface and requires moisture to activate. This herbicide saw use in Europe in the past, but then it went out of favor. Recently, metobromuron gained renewed attention when it was approved in the EU (around 2015) as an alternative to linuron in certain crops, under stricter regulatory oversight. It’s less known in the US, where it was never widely registered. In summary, metobromuron is a selective soil herbicide used mainly in potato and vegetable cultivation to prevent early weed competition, and its use has been mostly within Europe and a few other regions.

For metobromuron, potential exposure pathways are akin to those of other soil-applied herbicides in agriculture. **Dietary exposure** may occur through residues on or in harvested crops (like potatoes or other vegetables) treated with metobromuron. Given its use pre-emergence, residues at harvest are generally low, but monitoring ensures they stay below set limits. **Water exposure** is a consideration: metobromuron is moderately persistent and can be somewhat mobile; field studies indicate it may persist in soil and possibly be present in water bodies near treated fields under certain conditions. Thus, **drinking water** in farming regions could theoretically contain traces if runoff or leaching occurs, although as a newer re-introduced chemical, monitoring data is limited. **Occupational exposure** is relevant for farmers and applicators mixing or spraying metobromuron. Inhalation of dust from dry formulations or mist from liquid sprays can occur, and dermal contact can happen during handling or from contact with treated soil. Since metobromuron was often applied with ground equipment, applicators might experience low-level inhalation and skin exposure without proper PPE. **Drift exposure** to bystanders (e.g., neighboring fields or residents) is possible but minimal because it's applied to soil with relatively large droplets. **Indoor exposure** would not be expected, as metobromuron is not used in homes; any indoor presence would be via track-in of soil or dust from farm clothing. Now that metobromuron has been approved for use again in some areas (EU), these pathways are being managed via regulations (e.g., buffer zones to protect water, re-entry intervals to protect workers). Overall, ingestion (food, possibly water) is the main route for the public, whereas inhalation and dermal routes concern those applying the herbicide. With relatively controlled usage (currently mostly in professional agriculture), the exposure to the general population remains low and intermittent.
bullets: **Food ingestion** – eating produce (like peeled root vegetables or other crops) from fields treated with metobromuron, bearing any residual traces (ensured to be within legal limits)
**Drinking water** – consuming water from wells or streams adjacent to treated fields; metobromuron might leach or run off into water under some conditions
**Occupational inhalation** – breathing in spray mist or dust during herbicide application or mixing, affecting farmers and applicators
**Occupational dermal** – skin exposure when handling metobromuron concentrate, equipment, or contacting recently treated soil/plants (without gloves or protective clothing)

summary_sections.content: Metobromuron has a toxicological profile broadly similar to other phenylurea herbicides. It is of low acute toxicity in animal tests (oral LD50 in rats is high, indicating only slight acute toxicity). Workers handling it have not been reported to experience unique acute effects beyond general pesticide exposure symptoms if overexposed (such as skin irritation or mild systemic effects). However, there are indications of potential chronic hazards: metobromuron is flagged as a “possible carcinogen” in hazard summaries. Although full carcinogenicity studies are not widely publicized, this flag suggests that in long-term animal studies, it may have caused an increase in tumors or pre-cancerous changes. It is also worth noting that metobromuron is structurally similar to other urea herbicides that have been associated with endocrine effects (like linuron); thus, regulators have been cautious. Some studies under EU review likely evaluated its potential as an endocrine disruptor or reproductive toxin; however, it was not identified as a definite endocrine disruptor in the EU assessment (hence it was approved with standard risk mitigation). In metabolism, metobromuron breaks down into products such as monodemethyl-metobromuron (desmethoxy-metobromuron) and further into anilines and other compounds. These metabolites are typically less biologically active than the parent but could carry some toxicity (for example, phenylurea herbicides can metabolize to aniline derivatives that sometimes cause methemoglobinemia at high exposures). In human biomonitoring, there’s little data on metobromuron specifically, given its reintroduction is recent. If detected in blood or urine, it would signify recent exposure on the farm or via environmental contact. The body is expected to excrete it in urine relatively quickly (as seen with analogues). From a health perspective, authorities set exposure limits to ensure large safety margins; the EU, for instance, established an Acceptable Daily Intake (ADI) and Acute Reference Dose (ARfD) for metobromuron when approving it, taking into account any tumorigenic or toxic effects observed. In summary, metobromuron is considered low-risk for acute poisoning but carries some long-term toxicological concerns (like possible carcinogenicity) that are managed by regulation (limiting exposure). Users are advised to use protective gear to minimize any risk of skin sensitization or inhalation. No widespread human health incidents have been tied to metobromuron, but its hazard classification leads to it being handled with caution.

Metobromuron has an unusual regulatory history in that it was an older herbicide that fell out of use, then was revived as a replacement for banned substances in recent years. In the European Union, metobromuron was approved as a new active substance in 2015 (Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2015/1108) after a positive evaluation, specifically to allow its use on potatoes and other crops following the loss of linuron. This approval came with certain risk mitigation measures (like buffer zones to protect aquatic life, given its moderate persistence) and was set to expire in 2024. As per EU records, France was the rapporteur for its dossier, and metobromuron is not considered a candidate for substitution (it was deemed to have an acceptable profile relative to older herbicides). EU member states such as France, Germany, and others have since authorized metobromuron-containing herbicides for specific uses (e.g., Praxim for potatoes) under regulatory controls. In the UK, it was approved but with an expiration at end of 2024 for review. In the United States, metobromuron is not registered; it never gained EPA approval historically, and no current tolerance exists, meaning it cannot be used on US food crops. The same is true for many other countries outside the EU. **Monitoring**: As a relatively newly approved active in the EU, metobromuron is included in residue monitoring plans for relevant crops. Early monitoring ensures that residues on potatoes or other treated produce stay below the EU MRLs (Maximum Residue Limits) that were established during its approval (for example, a specific MRL in mg/kg for potatoes). Environmental monitoring may track metobromuron in water bodies near usage areas; given its mobility, EU states like France have likely added it to water surveillance lists. Occupational exposure monitoring would fall under general pesticide worker safety programs. Should any signals of concern arise (e.g., detection in groundwater above the 0.1 µg/L limit), regulators could revisit its conditions of use. It’s worth noting that because metobromuron was approved recently under modern standards, its regulatory dossier was thorough regarding health and eco-toxicology, which is why it attained approval whereas many older phenylureas did not. However, if new information (such as evidence of carcinogenicity or endocrine disruption) comes to light, its approval could be reassessed. As of now, metobromuron is legally used in parts of the EU and some other countries (Australia has evaluated it, for instance), and it is subject to the routine pesticide regulatory framework (periodic review, residue monitoring, etc.). With its approval set to last until 2027 in the EU (for plant protection products), regulators will continue to monitor compliance and any potential risks, ensuring that this “second life” herbicide remains within safety parameters.

Monolinuron is a phenylurea herbicide that is both selective and systemic. It was primarily used to control algae and broadleaf weeds in aquaculture and to a lesser extent in agriculture. In agriculture, monolinuron was applied pre- or post-emergence for weed control in crops like vegetables (e.g., beans, onions), potatoes, ornamental plants, and cereals. It inhibits photosynthesis in target plants. One notable application of monolinuron has been as an algicide in fish farming and aquariums to control algal blooms, due to its activity on simple photosynthetic organisms (it’s sometimes classified also as an algaecide). It was sold under names like "Preventol" for algal control and used in ponds and aquaria in very low concentrations. However, monolinuron’s use is limited and not widely approved in many developed countries. The herbicide was never as commonly used as related urea herbicides (like diuron or linuron). It has been largely phased out: for example, the EU did not renew monolinuron approvals (it’s listed as not approved), and it hasn’t been used in U.S. agriculture. Some continuing niche use exists, for instance in ornamental fish hobbyist products for algae control, but even those are restricted. In summary, monolinuron was once a minor herbicide for weed and algae control in various settings, but today it is not widely employed due to regulatory and market shifts.

Current exposure to monolinuron is rare because its use has been curtailed. Historically, exposure could occur through several pathways. **Dietary exposure** was possible by consuming produce from monolinuron-treated fields or fish from ponds where it was used as an algicide (though any residues in edible fish would likely be very low). For instance, vegetables like onions or ornamentals might have had residues if monolinuron was applied, but these uses have been largely discontinued in the developed world. **Water exposure** could have affected those who drank water or swam in water bodies treated with monolinuron for algae control; small water systems (like fish ponds) sometimes had monolinuron introduced, meaning **incidental ingestion or dermal contact** with such water was a route. **Occupational exposure** applied to workers who handled monolinuron formulations, whether in greenhouses or aquarium product manufacturing. Inhalation of dust from formulations or spray (if used in a greenhouse) and dermal contact during handling were the main routes. For aquarium use, hobbyists adding monolinuron to tanks could have a minor dermal exposure if they didn’t wear gloves. Because monolinuron is moderately volatile (actually it’s not very volatile, being a solid with low vapor pressure), inhalation of fumes was not a pathway – only particulate inhalation if any. **Indoor exposure** – interestingly, monolinuron’s use in aquariums implies a potential indoor pathway for fish owners, but these exposures would be extremely low and controlled by product instructions. In general, with monolinuron banned in agriculture in many places, the everyday person’s exposure is effectively zero. Any residual environmental presence (like trace amounts in sediments of former fish ponds) would be highly localized. In summary, while in the past one might encounter monolinuron via food or treated water, today the pathways are limited to specialized scenarios (like a user of an algicide product in a fish tank) and even those are diminishing as safer alternatives (or non-chemical methods) replace monolinuron.
bullets: **Ingestion of treated water** – drinking or accidentally swallowing water from ponds or aquaria treated with monolinuron for algae (an unlikely scenario for most people)
**Food consumption** – eating crops (or fish) that came from environments where monolinuron was applied (historically possible, now very rare)
**Occupational inhalation/dermal** – greenhouse workers or fish farm personnel who applied monolinuron could inhale dust or spray and have skin contact (no longer common due to disuse)
**Indoor aquarium use** – hobby aquarists adding monolinuron-based algae controls might contact the solution (skin exposure) or inhale a whiff of powder when dosing a tank (minimal exposure if any)

summary_sections.content: Monolinuron is considered to have low acute toxicity. Its LD50 values in animals indicate it is only slightly toxic if ingested; it also has low dermal toxicity. As a result, it was not associated with acute poisoning incidents in humans. It can cause mild skin or eye irritation upon direct contact (common for many herbicides), but it is not known as a skin sensitizer. Chronic or high-dose studies in animals showed that monolinuron’s toxic effects are limited. There’s no strong evidence linking monolinuron to carcinogenicity or severe organ toxicity, but comprehensive modern studies are few (given its relatively minor usage). Some sources classified monolinuron in a low concern category for human health. One area of note: many phenylurea herbicides have been evaluated for endocrine effects, and monolinuron was included in some screening (due to structural similarity).
